title: theresa may brexit deal eu mps blindfold questions future unanswered
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsMPs told UK will ‘choose’&nbsplater from ‘a spectrum’&nbspto decide how to trade&nbspwith the EU –&nbspamong range of issues kicked down the roadClick to followIndy PoliticsMPs of all parties accused Theresa May of delivering a “blindfold Brexit” after she admitted her deal left the public in the dark on a range of vital questions about Britain’s future.Decisions about future trade, the Irish border backstop, fisheries and whether the UK will remain tied to EU rules until after the next general election have all been shelved, a 26-page “political declaration” struck with the EU revealed.The admission came as the deal still looked doomed to defeat in a landmark vote next month – as both pro-&nbspand anti-EU Tories attacked it during feisty Commons exchanges in which&nbspfew supporters spoke up.Spain to vote against Theresa May’s Brexit deal over GibraltarSignificantly, two leading Brexiteers praised by Ms May for working with her on the document – Iain Duncan Smith and Owen Paterson – said they could not back it unless the backstop was stripped out.More than 80 Tories have criticised the package, pointing to a heavy defeat and a constitutional crisis, unless most can be talked around in the next few weeks of frantic arm-twisting.MPs protested that key decisions had been kicked down the road in crucial areas, including:* Future trade – where Ms May admitted the UK would “choose” later from “a spectrum”, balancing access to the EU against imposing greater controls.The document made no reference to “frictionless trade”, which the prime minister had promised. She said it was her “intention to work towards frictionless trade”.* The backstop – MPs will vote, in June 2020, whether to trigger the safeguard to prevent the return of checks at the Irish border, by the UK staying in the EU’s&nbspcustoms territory.* Ending the transition – which is due to run until December 2020, but could be extended until the end of 2022, past the June 2022 election, if MPs choose that option over triggering the backstop.Created with Sketch. Show all 12Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Britain's Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey arrives to attend the weekly meeting of the cabinet at 10 Downing Street in London. - Britain's Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey resigned from the cabinet over draft Brexit dealBritish Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab give a press conference at the end of  the final round of talks in Brexit negotiations at the European Commission in Brussels, BelgiumVice Chairman of the Conservative Party Rehman Chrishti tendered his resignation letter this afternoonParliamentary private secretary in the Department of Education Anne-Marie Trevelyan resigned stating that she cannot support the dealShailesh Vara who has quit as Minister of State for Northern Ireland, saying he cannot support Theresa May's Brexit agreement, which he said leaves the UK in a halfway house with no time limit on when we will finally be a sovereign nationBrexit minister Suella Braverman has resigned, stating “It is not what the British people, or my constituents, voted for in 2016.”Parliamentary private secretary to the ministry of justice Ranil Jayawardena resigned as he could not back the deal in good conscienceBritain's Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey arrives to attend the weekly meeting of the cabinet at 10 Downing Street in London. - Britain's Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey resigned from the cabinet over draft Brexit dealBritish Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab give a press conference at the end of  the final round of talks in Brexit negotiations at the European Commission in Brussels, BelgiumVice Chairman of the Conservative Party Rehman Chrishti tendered his resignation letter this afternoonParliamentary private secretary in the Department of Education Anne-Marie Trevelyan resigned stating that she cannot support the dealShailesh Vara who has quit as Minister of State for Northern Ireland, saying he cannot support Theresa May's Brexit agreement, which he said leaves the UK in a halfway house with no time limit on when we will finally be a sovereign nationBrexit minister Suella Braverman has resigned, stating “It is not what the British people, or my constituents, voted for in 2016.”Parliamentary private secretary to the ministry of justice Ranil Jayawardena resigned as he could not back the deal in good conscienceDowning Street insisted it had “won” the right to end the transition at any point over the two-year period, but admitted the UK could yet be locked in until the end of it.* Fisheries – future talks will decide whether EU boats still have access to UK waters in return for the UK enjoying tariff-free access to EU markets.Ross Thomson, a Scottish Tory MP, protested the deal meant “sovereignty over our waters sacrificed for a trade deal” – a fear heightened by Sabine Weyand, EU negotiator Michel Barnier’s deputy, saying it “covers both access to waters and market access”.The flimsy document fell far short of the extensive draft trade deal originally promised by the government before exit day next March – and has no legal force.Jeremy Corbyn confirmed Labour would vote against the deal, saying: “This is the blindfold Brexit we all feared – a leap into the dark. It falls far short of our – Labour’s – six tests.”Theresa May’s strategy for getting her Brexit deal through? MasochismMay faces growing Tory and DUP backlash over Brexit dealBrexit transition period can be extended until after next electionPolitical declaration on Brexit: what it says and what it meansFrictionless trade would end with EU under Theresa May’s Brexit dealNicola Sturgeon, the Scottish first minister, tweeted: “Lots of unicorns taking the place of facts about the future relationship ... it adds up to a blindfold Brexit.”Anna Soubry, a Tory supporter of a Final Say referendum, branded the deal a “syrup of warm sweet words” which delivered “no certainty, only aspiration”.Jeffrey Donaldson, the DUP chief whip, stopped short of confirming it would vote against the deal, but warned: “We need to see an end to the backstop.”Brexiteer Tories lined up to echo the threat.&nbspDominic Raab, who quit as Brexit secretary last week in protest, told her: “The backstop ties the UK to the customs union and single market rules with no voice and an EU veto over our exit.”Boris Johnson, the former foreign secretary, focused his criticism on the withdrawal agreement, on which the future partnership “will be based”, saying it “makes a complete nonsense of Brexit”.The prime minister’s spokesman confirmed the negotiations were finished as far as the UK was concerned – ruling out changes to the backstop, or additions to calm the anger of Brexiteers.And he confirmed the Chequers plan, which proposed adopting the EU’s “common rule book” for food and goods in the long term, had been abandoned.Asked if “Chequers had been chucked”, the spokesman said: “What the document provides for us to pursue whichever option we so chose ... there is a spectrum.”Asked if No 10 had a “plan B”&nbspif the deal was rejected, he insisted she was focused on “persuading all colleagues on the Conservative benches of the merits of the deal”.In her statement, Ms May urged MPs to recognise that “the British people want Brexit to be settled”, insisting: “The deal that will enable us to do this is now within our grasp.“In these crucial 72 hours ahead, I will do everything possible to deliver it for the British people.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsOfficials say aim is to make it ‘difficult to move’ for those deemed ‘untrustworthy’Click to followThe IndependentMillions of Chinese nationals have been blocked from booking flights or trains as Beijing seeks to implement its controversial&nbsp“social credit” system, which&nbspallows the government to closely monitor and judge each of its 1.3 billion citizens based on their behaviour and activity.The system, to be rolled out by 2020,&nbspaims to make it “difficult to move”&nbspfor those deemed “untrustworthy”, according to a&nbspdetailed plan&nbsppublished by the government this week.It will be used to reward or punish people and organisations for “trustworthiness” across a range of measures.A key part of the plan not only involves blacklisting people with low social credibility scores, but also “publicly disclosing&nbspthe records of enterprises and iniduals’ untrustworthiness on a regular basis”. The plan stated: “We will improve the credit blacklist system, publicly disclose the records of enterprises and iniduals’ untrustworthiness on a regular basis, and form a pattern of distrust and punishment.”Car ploughs into crowd outside primary school in China, killing fiveTrump aide says China could be evicted from WTO as trade war ramps upGovernment spending foreign aid money to promote fracking in ChinaFor those deemed untrustworthy, “everywhere is limited, and it is difficult to move, so that those who violate the law and lose the trust will pay a heavy price”.The credit system is already being rolled out in some areas and in recent months the Chinese state has blocked millions of people from booking flights and high-speed trains.According to the state-run news outlet Global Times, as of May this year, the government had&nbspblocked 11.14 million people from flights and 4.25 million from taking high-speed train trips.The state has also begun to clamp down on luxury options: 3&nbspmillion people are barred from getting business class train tickets, according to Channel News Asia.China tell ambassadors not to ‘interfere’ on Muslim re-education campsThe aim, according to Hou Yunchun, former deputy director of the development research centre of the State Council, is to make “discredited people become bankrupt”, he said earlier this year. The eastern state of Hangzou, southwest of Shanghai, is one area where a social credit system is already in place. People are awarded credit points for activities such as undertaking volunteer work and giving blood donations while those who violate traffic laws and charge “under-the-table” fees are punished. Other infractions reportedly include&nbspsmoking in non-smoking zones, buying too many video games and posting fake news online.Punishments are not clearly detailed in the government plan, but beyond making travel difficult, are also believed to include slowing internet speeds, reducing access to good schools for iniduals or their children, banning people from certain jobs, preventing booking at certain hotels and losing the right to own pets.Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Lebanese army soldiers march during a parade to mark the 75th anniversary of Lebanon's Independence Day, in Beirut, commemorating the liberation from the French Mandate on 22 November 1943Indian Muslim devotees wave flags as they parade atop vehicles along a street during Eid-Milad-Un-Nabi celebrations in Varanasi in the Indian state of Uttar PradeshAt least 50 people were killed and dozens more injured when a suicide bomber targeted a group of Muslim religious scholars in Kabul, officials in Afghanistan say.A view of the Fuego volcano eruption at sunrise, seen from El Rodeo, Escuintla, Guatemala. United Kingdom.Mrs May said a draft agreement on post-Brexit relations between the UK and the bloc had been agreed with Brussels ahead of a summit of EU leaders on Sunday.Mrs May said: The agreement including Gibraltar.It comes after a Spanish diplomatic source revealed Spain would vote against Mrs May&rsquos deal at a summit of EU leaders on Sunday due to the row over the British territory.On story: Initial reactions from MPs to the Political Declaration on the UK&rsquos future relationship with the EU suggested that at least 88 Tory MPs will oppose the deal in the so-called &ldquomeaningful vote that the Government promised Parliament.&nbspGiven that the Prime Minister only has a working majority of 10 when her fractious allies in the Democratic Unionist Party are included, Mr Smith and his whipping team will have to twist a lot of arms and whisper gentle persuasions into many ears to have any hope of turning the balance in the Government&rsquos favour.                What is the withdrawal agreement? What is the political declaration?                May's Brexit deal could keep UK locked to EU until next election Yet Mrs May has a record of winning Commons votes against what seem insurmountable odds. Threatened revolts by both Tory Remainers and Brexiteers over the last year have dwindled before the isions took place.&nbspMany Tories unhappy with aspects of the deal are also beginning to fret that the party is losing its former reputation for providing strong and stable government.&nbspThe instinct for electoral survival is likely to become a growing factor as the &ldquomeaningful vote approaches, particularly if MPs find voters on the doorsteps in the constituencies increasingly want Brexit to be sorted as soon as possible and sympathetic to the efforts made by the Prime Minister to deal with the challenge.Prime Minister Theresa May's deal looks short of support for ministers (Image: Jack TaylorGetty Images)MPs want Brexit to be sorted as soon as possible (Image: Chris RatcliffeBloomberg via Getty Images)Mrs May will have to make more compromises and offer more guarantees to have any hope of winning the vote. She may well lose at least one Commons ision and be forced to find a way of wrenching more concessions out of Brussels.If wavering Tory Eurosceptics are to be won over, she must go further allaying concerns that the so-called Irish backstop will be a trap designed to keep the UK tied to the EU forever.Yet the Prime Minister and her team have proved adept at finding last-ditch ways to appease her critics. Mrs May and her Chief Whip face some hard thinking on how to make the Commons arithmetic work in their favour.

story: Royal expert Robert Jobson, who has nearly 30 years of experience in the monarchy, said the Queen, 92, travels via the Royal train rather than flying. Mr Jobson has spent over a year alongside Prince Charles as part of a new book called Charles at Seventy: Thoughts, Hopes and Dreams where he reveals fresh material and exclusive insight into the Royal Family.                Prince Charles' sweet message to royal fans about Meghan and HarrySpeaking to Express, Mr Jobson said: &ldquoOf course, at 92, 93 next birthday, she is not doing more&nbsplong-haul&nbspflights. She did fly in 2015 to Germany by private jet.&ldquoBut the reality is, they use the royal train a lot. She has away days and she still carries them out to the best of her ability.&ldquoBecause she is not travelling the Prince of Wales does most of&nbspthe, if you like, heavy lifting of the monarchy and when he travels abroad most of his duties are perceived to be like&nbspstate visits more than anything else.Mr Jobson referenced Prince Charles&rsquo trip to the Middle East where he was treated as if he &ldquowas already king, with people bowing down to the Prince of Wales.Queen Elizabeth II has not flown on an aeroplane since 2015 (Image: )He added: &ldquoWith the Queen not able to do some of these things, such as, as we saw recently he took the lead of the Cenotaph where he lead the nation in mourning.&ldquoHe laid the nation&rsquos wreath, the Queen&rsquos wreath, he laid it on her behalf.The royals often fly with British Airways when travelling abroad. The Queen first flew on a British Airways plane in 1952, when she found out about her father's death, she then proceeded to use the British airline for another fifty years.But it is not the only rule that the Royal Family follow.The next in line to the throne is rarely allowed to travel with the preceding heir on the same flight, on the occasion that an accident occurred.However, William broke this when travelling with his son, Prince George when he was just nine months.He now regularly travels on the same plane with his family despite this long tradition.It is rumoured that he had to ask his grandmother Queen Elizabeth for permission before joining his son onboard.

story: After decades of lobbying politicians and pressure groups on his favourites causes, from town planning, architecture, alternative medicine, the environment and organic farming techniques, Prince Charles claims he&rsquos &ldquonot stupid&rsquo and understands the need to be non-political when he ascends the throne. For years there has been concern that Prince Charles would attempt to influence political and public decision-making, unlike his mother Queen Elizabeth, 92, who is scrupulously non-political. In &ldquoCharles, Prince of Wales, author Anthony Holden describes how Charles felt about democracy.The Prince professed himself to be &ldquotroubled by the fact that the voters today tend to go for a particular party and not for the inidual candidate, because they vote for the politics of a party.He thought it &ldquowrong that a below-par Conservative candidate should win votes simply because he toed the party line against nationalism or the abolition of the public school.Prince Charles made a risqu&eacute joke to Parliament during his trip to Bermuda for the 350th anniversary of the island&rsquos Parliament.Charles joked: &ldquoBearing in mind I am the first Charles to have anything to do with Parliament for 350 years, I might have turned nasty and dissolved you.There are no formal rules on what royals can or cannot say in public (Image: Getty)Such interventions in matters of public debate have stoked concern for those who believe the royals should not get involved in such affairsThe Prince of Wales has created his own role as a royal activist and entrepreneur. His organisation, The Prince&rsquos Charities, is the UK&rsquos largest multi-cause charity, and he was an early promoter of corporate social responsibility.Unlike the Queen, Prince Charles has been outspoken on subjects from London&rsquos architecture to nanotechnology. He has been a figurehead for rallying world leaders to tackle climate change, and a dogged opponent of GM crops.Although there are no formal rules on what royals can or cannot say in public, an unwritten assumption is that they cannot meddle with party politics.Prince Charles made a risqu&eacute joke to Parliament during his trip to Bermuda (Image: Getty)Ministers in the last Labour government have said he tried to influence policy on issues such as grammar schools and homeopathic medicine.There is also the ongoing legal saga over the so-called &lsquoblack spider&rsquo memos, a collection of letters he wrote to government ministers.Many are sympathetic to Prince Charles's involvement in politics up to now. As one former minister says, &ldquoif you are waiting to be king ... and you&rsquove waited a very long time, you genuinely have to engage in something or you&rsquod go spare.Yet others say that a king who cares about his country must make his opinions heard. If Prince Charles becomes king he has a duty to voice his views if he is to remain relevant to society.

story: This weeks Question Time comes from Cannock in Staffordshire (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME )The discussion is likely to focus on the outlined Brexit deal agreed by the UK and EU, before Prime Minister Theresa May heads to Brussels for more negotiations and an EU leaders summit where the final deal could be confirmed.Mrs May may struggle to get her deal through Parliament, with a number of her backbenchers vowing to join the Labour opposition in attempting to resign. Cannock Chase, the local parliamentary constituency is a eurosceptic stronghold which backed &lsquoLeave&rsquo by 68.5 percent to 31.5 percent during the EU membership referendum.Joining David Dimbleby today are Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley, Shadow Treasury Minister Clive Lewis, broadcaster Julia Hartley-Brewer, managing director of Icelands Supermarkets Richard Walker and the former chair of the Equalities and Human Rights Commission, Trevor Philips.&nbspFollow below for live updates&hellip                Philip Hammond breaks silence on Theresa May&rsquos Brexit pact11.43pm update: That&rsquos it for this week!&nbspDavid Dimbleby wraps up this weeks edition of Question Time, and says next week&rsquos episode will be from Penzance in Cornwall.&nbspMeanwhile in other Question Time news there are reports Fiona Bruce is being considered as a replacement for Mr Dimbleby when he steps down, making her the first women to host the show.&nbspThanks a lot for sticking with us and goodnight!&nbsp11.43pm update: &lsquoI lay a big part of the blame at universal credit&rsquo&nbspBusinessman Richard Walker says &lsquoI lay a big part of the blame at universal credit&rsquo. former Chair of the Equalities and Human Rights Commission (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME )11.26pm update: &ldquoI find gambling quite scary&nbspBroadcaster Julia Hartley-Brewer says &ldquoI find gambling quite scary.&nbspDescribes gambling addiction as &ldquoa nasty nasty thing and describes Tony Blair&rsquos deregulation of the gambling industry as &ldquodisastrous.&nbspGoes on to predict we will end up with stricter gambling regulations.&nbsp11.20pm update: New Question - should we celebrate the success of Denise Coates and Bet365?&nbspA new question on whether we should celebrate the success of Denise Coates, the founder of gambling firm Bet365, who paid herself &pound265 million in 2017.&nbspMr Walker, a fellow businessperson, describes it as &ldquoan absence amount of money. However suggests high salaries are acceptable for the heads of companies which contribute to the community. Also calls for more safeguards to stop gambling companies targeting children.&nbspHe goes on to claim Bet365 is domiciled in Gibraltar, and speculates about what this means for its tax arrangements. &nbsp11.15pm update: Does Mrs May&rsquos Brexit mean remain?&nbspA new, though clearly interconnected, audience question - &ldquoDoes Mrs May&rsquos Brexit mean remain?&nbspTory Karen Bradley insists it does, saying it allows the UK to &ldquosign independent trade deals and delivers &ldquoa great relationship with Europe.&nbspAdds deal: &ldquoDelivers on the Brexit result and will deliver for the United Kingdom.&nbspNorthern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME)11.12pm update: &lsquoTheresa May will be down at the job centre&rsquo&nbspAn audiance member describes Mrs May&rsquos agreement as a &ldquododgy deal.&nbspSays he expects to see &ldquoTheresa May down the jobs centre shortly.&nbspMr Philips says Labour is peddling &ldquoutter fantasy by claiming the deal can be reopened. Insists if Parliament can&rsquot do the job we should have a second referendum between this deal and no-deal.&nbsp11.08pm update: Audience member calls for &ldquosecond vote&nbspAn audience member has urged a second Brexit vote on the basis that what&rsquos on offer is so different to what had been promised.&nbspThis is rejected by Minister Karen Bradley who says a referendum has already taken place.&nbspMs Bradley is asked whether Mrs May will resign if she can&rsquot get her deal through the Commons. Doesn&rsquot answer the question.&nbsp11.05pm update: &ldquoI&rsquom more than happy with no deal&nbspMs Hartley-Brewer says &ldquoI&rsquom more than happy with a no-deal in answer to an audience members question.&nbspHowever Mr Walker fires back saying the country isn&rsquot ready for a second referendum.&nbspA lady, who describes herself as a remainer who would like a second referendum, urges Labour to get behind the deal.&nbspLabour&rsquos Clive Lewis, a little unsurprisingly, calls for a General Election. Says a second referendum could be an option but refuses to say which way he would vote.&nbspThe BBC Question Time panel  (Image: BBC QUESTION TIME )11.02pm update: Not accepting the deal means &ldquovoting for chaos&nbspFormer Human Rights Commission head Trevor Philips says he voted Remain but &ldquowe lost, and I have to accept that. Describes deal as &ldquoworst deal in the world, except for all the other deals which are on offer.&nbspMr Philips says: I would vote for this deal because I think there are more important things for our Parliament to be getting on with.&nbspMr Walker also backs the agreement saying: We have to back this deal because it gives us a roadmap to the future.&nbsp11.00pm update: Not accepting the deal means &ldquovoting for chaos&nbspMs Bradley says rejecting the deal would mean &ldquovoting for chaos. Expresses confidence the deal can pass the House of Commons despite an apparent majority against it.&nbspUrges MPs who oppose the deal to &ldquospeak to their constituents.&nbspMs Hartley-Brewer intervenes asking whether Ms Bradley thinks former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, who resigned over the deal, doesn&rsquot understand the deal.&nbsp10.58pm update: &lsquoOnly Philip May agrees with the Prime Minister&rsquo&nbspBrexit backing broadcaster Julia Hartley-Brewer says Mrs May has alienated the whole country and the only person who likely approves of her Brexit deal is her own husband Philip.&nbspDescribes the deal as &ldquoworst than remaining in the EU. Says under the deal &ldquowe won&rsquot even have the right to leave the customs union unless the other 27 countries agree.&nbspNorthern Ireland Minister Karen Bradley says deal &ldquodelivers the result of the referendum and allows Britain &ldquoto strike deals globally.&nbsp10.55pm update: &lsquoMay has ided Britain&rsquo&nbspLabour&rsquos Clive Lewis accuses the Prime Minister of iding the country over Brexit, angering many &lsquoRemain&rsquo voters who initially accepted the result.&nbspHe argues the Prime Minister to &ldquostep aside for the Labour Party.&nbspRichard Walker, managing director of Iceland&rsquos Supermarkets and leave voter, describes it as &ldquoa good deal.&nbspSays: &ldquoIt keeps us on good terms with the EU when we&rsquore about to start the biggest negotiation, for the free trade agreement.&nbsp10.45pm update: We&rsquore underway!&nbspQuestion Time has started on BBC1.&nbspHost David Dimbleby introduces the panel who get a warm round of applause from the audience.&nbspFirst question, presumably on Brexit, is &ldquohaving tried to please all the people has Theresa May succeeded in pleasing none?&nbsp10.35pm update: Question Time starts at 10.45pm&nbspJust 10 minutes until Question Time gets under way on BBC1.&nbspFollowing the publication earlier today of the so-called political declaration, a statement of intent for future UK-EU relations after Brexit which accompanies the draft EU exit deal, the panel will have plenty to talk about.&nbspThis is a separate document to the 585 page withdrawal&nbspagreement which has provoked so much controversy.&nbspSo strap in, it should be a fiesty one!&nbsp

story: A leaked version of the &ldquopolitical declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship obtained by Express shows Brussels and Westminster will use &ldquobest endeavours to reach a fisheries deal before July 1 2020. The document reads: &ldquoWithin the context of the overall economic partnership the parties should establish a new fisheries agreement on, inter alia, access to waters and quota shares. &ldquoThe parties will use their best endeavours to conclude and ratify their new fisheries agreement by July 1 2020 in order for it to be in place n time to be used for determining fishing opportunities for the first year after the transition.                Tory minister reveals his SECRET Brexit chat with Michel Barnier                 Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling &lsquoon the back foot&rsquoBrussels negotiator Michel Barnier was told during a series of crunch meetings before the document's leak that sections on potential access to UK fishing must be bulked up.France argued that EU fishing vessels should be allowed access to the UK's waters as part of any future trade deal that allows Britain access to the single market.Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Belgium and Denmark also put Mr Barnier's task force under pressure to ensure a deal would be pushed in the blue print for a future trade deal.The political declaration is the non-binding roadmap that UK and EU officials will use to negotiate the future trading and security relationship after Brexit.Brexit news: Political declaration shows UK will commit to striking fishing deal with EU (Image: )The 26-page blueprint has grown from seven pages after its initial publication alongside the Brexit withdrawal agreement last week.It charts future ideas, plans and promises on how the UK and EU can work together on trade and security.After late night talks between Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels on Wednesday, the European Commission President told the European Council that an agreement had been reached between UK and EU officials.The document will now be circulated around member states to review ahead of Sunday's special Brexit summit, where EU leaders will rubber stamp the plans.Mr Tusk wrote on Twitter: I have just sent to EU27 a draft political declaration on the future relationship between EU and UK.The Commission President has informed me that it has been agreed at negotiators' level and agreed in principle at political level, subject to the endorsement of the leaders.                How Greece had 17 HOURS to avoid abyss - what May is facing...                 Merkel desperate for Spain to 'SHUT UP' &ndash FEARS EU pushing UK too farBoth sides have agreed to build and improve on the single customs territory provided for in the Withdrawal Agreement, which has been drawn out in previous European Council negotiating guidelines.This partnership will be comprehensive, encompassing a free trade area as well as wider sectoral cooperation where it is in the mutual interest of both parties, the declaration adds.It will be underpinned by provisions ensuring a level playing field for open and fair competition.It should facilitate trade and investment between the Parties to the extent possible, while respecting the integrity of the Union's Single Market and the Customs Union as well as the United Kingdom's internal market, and recognising the development of an independent trade policy by the United Kingdom beyond this economic partnership.In an olive branch to Mrs May in her fight to keep rebel Tory MPs under control, Brussels have allowed their maximum facilitation to be considered as an option to avoid the Irish backstop, the insurance policy to avoid a hard border on Ireland.The declaration reads: The Parties recall their determination to replace the backstop solution on Northern Ireland by a subsequent agreement that establishes alternative arrangements for ensuring the absence of a hard border on the island of Ireland on a permanent footing.Such facilitative arrangements and technologies will also be considered in developing any alternative arrangements for ensuring the absence of a hard border on the island of Ireland on a permanent footing, it adds.Britain will also commit to developing a level playing field with Brussels after a number of member states tabled concerns about the UK securing an economic advantage by undercutting EU rules and standards.The future relationship must ensure open and fair competition, the document reads.Provisions to ensure this should cover state aid, competition, social and employment standards, environmental standards, climate change, and relevant tax matters, building on the level playing field arrangements provided for in the Withdrawal Agreement and commensurate with the overall economic relationship.This will likely change as French President Emmanual Macron, the driving force behind the demands, takes to the negotiating table on Sunday.Influential Conservative MEP David Campbell Bannerman said the UK's commitment was worrying.Mr Campbell Banner, who is championing a 'Super Canada deal' also suggested tax matters should be left as a sovereign decision by the UK Government.He said: While I broadly welcome on trade an agreement that definitely looks like Super Canada and not Chequers, this clause is worrying.One of the main benefits of Brexit is the ability to cut EU overregulation, this ties our hands.Tax matters are a clear sovereign area, the EU is worried about the UK becoming super competitive and trying to hold us back, he adds.

Please, please wake up!Brexit news: Radio host Shelagh Fogarty left speechless by angry Brexiteer (Image: LBC)It comes as the Prime Minister published a drafted 26-page Political Declaration which paints the first picture of how the future relationship will look once the UK leaves the European Union.The document, yet to be approved by EU leaders at Sunday&rsquos summit, offers hope to &ldquobuild and improve on the single customs territory.It also outlines that alternative arrangements will be considered to supersede the controversial backstop agreed by Mrs May with the EU in the withdrawal agreement.&nbspThe document reads: &ldquoThe Parties will put in place ambitious customs arrangements, in pursuit of their overall objectives.&ldquoIn doing so, the Parties envisage making use of all available facilitative arrangements and technologies, in full respect of their legal orders and ensuring that customs authorities are able to protect the Parties&rsquo respective financial interests and enforce public policies.&ldquoTo this end, they intend to consider mutual recognition of trusted traders&rsquo programmes, administrative cooperation in customs matters and mutual assistance, including for the recovery of claims related to taxes and duties, and through the exchange of information to combat customs fraud and other illegal activity.&ldquoSuch facilitative arrangements and technologies will also be considered in developing any alternative arrangements for ensuring the absence of a hard border on the island of Ireland on a permanent footing, it adds.The possible solution to the Irish backstop was proposed to the Prime Minister by Tory Brexiteers Iain Duncan-Smith and Owen Paterson and comes as a victory for hard Brexiteers on the Conservative backbench.However, the agreement still leaves Theresa May with a tough task to convince MPs on her deal with&nbsplittle&nbsppromise of frictionless trade and with the UK likely to remain in a customs union.

story: 12-metre long bus will carry up to 42 people (Image: Fusion Processing)Work on the &pound6million trial will begin next year, with the first self-driving&nbspvehicles crossing the bridge in 2020 before passengers are let on board in 2021.&nbspEach 12-metre long bus will carry up to 42 people and will be converted from existing single-deckers.&nbspA fully qualified driver will remain on board at all times as the fleet travel 14 miles from Ferrytoll Park &amp Ride in Fife and the Edinburgh Park train and tram interchange, making use of the dedicated public transport corridor on the Forth Road Bridge.                Fully self-parking cars could be on the roads in the UK within the ...                Volvo 360c concept car teaser trailer reveals new driverless vehicl...Holyrood Transport Secretary Michael Matheson said: &ldquoThe deployment of these vehicles in Scotland will bring transformative change to the way we travel.The partnership of firms behind the project said buses on the route could make an estimated 10,000 journeys a week if they ran every 20 minutes.The pilot is being led by self-driving technology firm Fusion Processing in co-operation with Transport Scotland, bus firm Stagecoach and manufacturer Alexander Dennis.Passengers will be let on board in 2021 (Image: Fusion Processing)Work on the five Alexander Dennis Enviro200 buses is due to begin next year at the firm&rsquos manufacturing depot in Guildford, Surrey, with closed trials taking place before they hit the road.Funding of &pound4.35million has been awarded by the UK Government, with investment from the firms involved taking the total to more than &pound6million.In a joint statement, the project&rsquos partners said: &ldquoWe&rsquore delighted to have been awarded this funding and we are excited to further test the potential for autonomous technology within public transport using full size single deck&nbspbuses, which so far has not been achieved anywhere else in the world.

story: A spokesman for 10 Downing Street told Express the Government will have 21 days to come back with a new plan after &ndash and if &ndash Parliament votes down her draft Brexit Withdrawal&nbspAgreement. Only then, both the House of Commons and the House of Lords will be allowed to debate the new proposal under a so-called motion in neutral terms.                Amber Rudd rules out NO DEAL Brexit with SHOCK warning for Brexiteers                May's Brexit deal could keep UK locked to EU until next election According to the Institute for Government, a &ldquono vote could only send the Government back to the negotiating table in two remote scenarios.If the UK Parliamentary vote takes place early enough, then there could be time for UK Parliamentary scrutiny, followed by a UK Parliamentary rejection, followed by further negotiations until the end date provided by the triggering of Article 50 is reached - in this case, 29th March 2019.However, the current timetable does not appear to allow sufficient time for this process. In any case, further negotiations would only be possible if other European countries were also prepared to continue.A late &ldquono vote could also be followed by further negotiations, but only if the two-year window dictated by Article 50 is extended.That can only happen with the unanimous agreement of the other member states. It is not within MPs' remit to extend the negotiating period unilaterally.It is also still unclear whether Parliament will be able to vote in favour or against a no deal scenario despite Amber Rudd's statement MPs would stop a no deal outcome.The Work and Pensions Secretary said: &ldquoThat vote when it comes to it, people have to consider, and I know all my colleagues will, very carefully, whether, on the balance, they think that delivering on the referendum result and this deal, is going to give the right outcome for the country.&ldquoIf it doesn&rsquot get through, anything could happen. But hard work lies ahead.&ldquoA 20-page vision needs to become a 2,000-page agreement that secures trade and jobs before the spectre of no deal can be put to rest.However, ITV reported the organisation&rsquos head of EU negotiations, Nicole Sykes, said there was &ldquono need to give credit to the negotiators in the statement &ldquobecause it&rsquos not a good deal.The message was inadvertently sent to the broadcaster at the foot of the official statement.READ MORE:&nbsp&lsquoYou CANNOT negotiate with EU!' - Ex-Greek finance minister                Commons ROARS as May SAVAGES Corbyn &ndash ridicules six Labour Party tests                Wetherspoons boss outlines EXACTLY why UK should leave with no dealThe Prime Minister will attend a Brussels summit this Sunday to agree Brexit terms (Image: )In its response to ITV, the CBI said the broadcaster &ldquoreproduced private debate knowing it&rsquos not CBI position.Ms Fairbairn said: &ldquoThis deal is not perfect &ndash business is both clear and honest on this.&ldquoBut it is the best option we have for avoiding a cliff edge and building a pathway to a good future deal.&ldquoThat is progress, we should not go backwards.The news of the blunder is also embarrassing for the Prime Minister, who on Monday attempted to sell her Brexit vision to the CBI&rsquos annual conference, imploring voters to &ldquolisten to what business is saying.READ MORE:&nbspIs this the solution to the Brexit backstop NO ONE ever thought of?The leaked emails were also embarrassing for Theresa May  (Image: )The gaffe instigated indignant reactions from both sides of the Brexit debate on Thursday.Former Tory MP and ex-Brexit advisor Stewart Jackson said: &ldquoSpeaking with a forked tongue for their own short-term narrow interests? You could knock me down with a feather.Labour MP Wes Streeting, who backs a second referendum, said: Despite the CBI's public support, it is clear that even the Government&rsquos biggest business backers think this is a bad deal for Britain.There is no support in Parliament, among business or in the country for a deal which takes away control and makes people poorer.Mrs May&rsquos 26-page document was met with varying degrees of criticism as it was unveiled on Thursday, resulting in a fiery Commons exchange.READ MORE:&nbsp'Paying EU for decades!' Farage issues SHOCK warning over Brexit billMrs May at the annual CBI conference on Monday (Image: )The heated debate saw senior ERG members Iain Duncan Smith and Boris Johnson brand the deal a &ldquosell-out and &ldquocomplete nonsense of Brexit respectively.The leader of the Opposition, Jeremy Corbyn, said the deal was &ldquo26 pages of waffle and &ldquothe worst of all worlds.He said: &ldquoThe only certainty contained within these pages is that the transition period will have to be extended or we will end up with backstop and no exit.&ldquoIt represents the worst of all worlds, no say over the rules that will continue to apply and no certainty to the future.But the Prime Minister insisted the deal was the best way forward, arguing &ldquoBrexit is within our grasp.She added: &ldquoThe British people want Brexit to be settled.&ldquoThey want a good deal that sets us on course for a brighter future.&ldquoAnd they want us to come together as a country and to move on to focus on the big issues at home, like our NHS.

title: david cameron prime minister brexit steve hilton
story: The ex-PM could make a comebackhis successor is forced to stand down, according to his former guru.Steve Hilton, Mr Camerons director of strategy, said his old boss could be the best hope for Britain.He suggested one reason the Brexit process has been so tricky is that Mr Cameron quit immediately after the EU referendum.Writing in the Sunday Times, Mr Hilton said: What Britain needs above all is a leader with the confidence and the character to command respect and bring people together from all sides of this bruising two-year national meltdown.If there is a Conservative party leadership election, no doubt many able MPs will throw their hat in the ring.But there’s one name that should also be on the list - David Cameron.Considering where we are now, David Cameron’sto No could in fact be the best hope for Britain.Mr Hilton blasted Mrs Mays proposed Brexit deal - but claimed it would have been almost impossible to negotiate a better one.Instead he called for Britain to leave the EU without any deal, and use it as an opportunity to re-imagine the countrys economy.The Sun revealed earlier this month that Mr Cameron is keen toto frontline politics because hes bored s***less.The former Prime Minister left Parliament in , a few months after leaving Downing Street.But he likes the idea of making an unexpected comeback, possibly in the key role of Foreign Secretary.

title: im a celebrity noel edmonds
story: With or without his rehab ­certicate. Preferably driving John Barrowman’s jeep.But definitely presenting I’m A Celebrity . . . Get Me Out Of Here! which kicked off, on Sunday night, with Dec hosting and Holly ­Willoughby hanging around like a competition winner.An arrangement that would be unsustainable in other years. I’m prepared to cut the  series some slack, though, for two reasons.First, it is purely a temporary pairing and, second, ITV has promised me Noel Edmonds, who shouldn’t just have been the first one in the camp, he should’ve been choppered in about eight years ago, when the contestants started all this “bonding” rubbish, which has ruined more series than I care to remember.Oh, what some of them could’ve done with a one-man feud generator like Noel, whose Wikipedia entry will give you a fair idea of his inner turmoil even before you get to the bit where he says: “When I die, my energy willto where it came from.” Ilford He’s also got a le-size mannequin doll called Candice, who accompanies him everywhere and would be a more than welcome replacement for a few of the camp mates, who’ve got a bit of a Rita Who and Knob Too feel about them this year.The knob part of that equation, fairly obviously, is all-singing, all-dancing John Barrowman “MBE” , who described himself as “fabulous”, “an icon” and “down-to-earth” within the space of one sentence, on Sunday, and was wrong on every count.He also hit on the yacht waiter, using one of his dance moves.“It’s a pas de bourrée. Kick ball, change and turn. Can you do that ”“I’m not allowed.”Not even the kick balls bit Shame. He needs someone to calm him down.Although, as horrendous as it must be to live with, I don’t mind Barrowman on I’m A Celeb, as the show does need a massive irritant to get under everyone’s skin.On similar grounds, I also welcome EastEnders’ Rita Simons, who looks like she might have a tantrum or two in her, Nick Knowles, who will be incapable of stling his Sir Galahad complex, and Harry Redknapp, just because he’s Harry Redknapp.Of the others The public jury’s probably still out on Emily Atack and The Chase Governess Anne Hegerty, who “used to be a Brownie”, as well as eating a lot of them.Mentally, though, I have already completely written off Coronation Street’s Sair Khan, some bloke off Hollyoaks, The Vamps’ James McVey and X Factor’s Fleur East, who arrived dressed as a dispatch rider for the first episode.Possibly for the very good reason she’s now working as one.This might sound like a hasty and fairly damning assessment, I realise, but compared to some series, four solidly promising bookings isn’t actually a bad .What it very clearly needs, though, is Edmonds, because, without him, Sunday’s opening episode, for all its high adrenaline thrills, became a bit of a drag.It usually does, of course, as the celebs haven’t yet let their guard drop.But, in this instance it meant the spotlight fell on Holly Willoughby, and you quickly realised Dec hasn’t had to work this hard since he tried bouncing jokes off Hogan the Koala.Just as Edmonds could turn out to be a massive disappointment, Holly Willoughby could get the hang of I’m A Celeb, obviously.At the moment, though, her one signicant contribution came after the parachuting challenge when she asked: “How come Shane had a helmet and Emily didn’t ”’Cos the bloke was doing all the hard work and she was just hanging around.Buckle up, Dec.Alastair Campbell’s far-too-frequent Good Morning Britain appearances always proving as welcome as a turd in a swimming pool.Strictly stars forever banging on about reaching Blackpool without ever mentioning it means they get paid more.Every wretched, product-placing second of the entertainment on Friday’s Children In Need.And particularly EastEnders’ big song-and-dance routine, which had the Disney Company’s Angela Affinita claiming: “We have Letitia Dean actually interacting with Mickey Mouse.”Good luck with that one, Mickey.IF you want to know just how brutally British republicans would mistreat the Royal Family,they ever came to power, just take a look at what those who claim to love them the most do to the Windsors now.Stuff like We Are Most Amused And Amazed, a th birthday tribute, hosted by Armstrong  Miller, on ITV, that probably left the future King Charles III thinking Charles I got off lightly.Two hours of canned laughter and pick-a-card-any-card magical tw*ttery with the likes of Sandi Toksvig, who took  seconds to remind us she’s gay, Omid Djalili, who took an entire  seconds to remind us he’s Iranian, and Rowan Atkinson, who rather set the evening’s tone by announcing: “As the more perceptive of you will have noticed, this is hell.”There was a family of German illusionists as well, which I thought was a bit insensitive, given the royal circumstances, plus Sooty  Sweep and a lot of grovelling from randoms, like Cheryl Tweedy and Kylie Minogue.Presumably because they could both be guaranteed to keep a straight face when describing the birthday boy as “a style icon” and “philanthropist”.Then, at the end of it all, dear old Charles shuffled on, waved and thanked everybody.And he may even have meant every syllable of it as well, given that Alexander Armstrong thrilled the Palladium crowd by deciding not to sing.Truly, the Royal Family is the most wondrous thing.Jenny Eclair: “The last thing any woman needs, during or after the menopause, is a bothersome vagina.”Tough, you’ve got one for another  minutes.MEANWHILE, desperate times call for desperate means at the rugby, as England trail Japan - and Sir Clive Woodward suggests: “We’ve got to start using our physicality, just outside the rucks, to suck these Japanese guys.”A WELCOME antidote to all of the lazy, repetitive, biased, hideously self-satisfied and right-on comedy broadcast by the BBC and Channel  finally reappeared, on Saturday night.Michael McIntyre’s Big Show, on BBC, which has to be the most perfectly judged hour of television, all year.A quota-free joy that’s warm, funny and has mainstream appeal, without ever being too cloying, safe, predictable or slick, as you will have noticed when Lionel Blair completely sabotaged the “Unexpected Star” reveal, in a pop-up Zimmer frame shop, with -year-old David Owen.“Say hello to David,” McIntyre whispered into his ear-piece.“Hello David!”Pause. “How does he know my name’s David ”Well, quite. Among his other gts, though, Michael McIntyre, above, has the ability to charm and ad-lib his way out of these situations, which gives his Big Show a seat-of-its-pants feel, despite being one of the most carefully structured formats on television.As anyone with a brain can see, in fact, it should be the blueprint for almost everything BBC comedy does.So I can pretty much guarantee, this time next year, Have I Got News, The Mash Report and Frankie Boyle’s New World Order will still be telling us how much they hate Brexit and Donald Trump and someone from the BBC, on £, a year, will be assuring licence-payers: “Sara Pascoe is the future of comedy.”Pointless Celebrities: “Hi, I’m Luisa Omielan and I’m a comedian.” Bless.And Good Morning Britain, Susanna Reid: “I don’t think the word ambition applies to me. I don’t have any ambition.”WHO said the following on live TV, last week “The colon has been mobilised and we’re very close to the moment the bowel’s coming out.”A Nicky Campbell on Channel ’s Removing The Tumour B Theresa May in Downing Street Joe Lycett: “Measuring the strength of earth-quakes, the Richter scale was invented by Charles who ”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Between Newcastle and Gateshead, the King Edward Bridge spans what river ”And Joe Lycett: “Nicola Sturgeon, a Scot or a fish ”Kristy: “A fish.”MICHAEL McIntyre’s Big Show. Paddy Considine, Jessica Raines and Bel Powley all performing brilliantly in BBC’s Informer.Channel ’s strangely addictive and reassuring live operations series, with Nicky Campbell.Prime-Minister-in-waiting Johnny Mercer MP breezing through Celebrity Hunted, without dear old Kay Burley to encumber him.Scotland playing olé football against the mighty Albania.And the politically incorrect brilliance of the response Chase contestant Bethan gave to Bradley Walsh’s question: “The name of what German ­company comes from the name of founder Adolf Dassler ”“Hitler.”Compiled by Graham WrayGary Neville: “Lingard has his hands in his head.”Michael Dawson: “It’s an unexpected start for Spurs because they didn’t expect that.”Trevor Bayliss: “We’ve come to Sri Lanka to play in conditions which are foreign to us.”And Paul Merson: “A poor finish from Vardy, but that’s him at his best.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal mars bar brexit jane moore
story: The operative word being “could”, of course. Same with Dairy Milk and Picnic bars too, apparently.Whatever, surely it’s a win-win situation  No more being bossed about by unelected Eurocrats and help tackle the obesity tooth rot crisis at the same time. But really, does anyone actually believe this Project Fear twaddle  No one has yet suggested that “no deal will see an end to Brussels sprouts”, but it can only be a matter of time.Meanwhile, we are still being peddled the prospect of medication piling up at the border, the entire City of London decamping to Paris, flights being grounded at the stroke of midnight on March , gridlocked motorwaysand “civil unrest”.Enough already. Like .million others, I voted for Brexit on the basis thatthe EU wouldn’t give us a mutually beneficial deal then we would simply leave without one.It’s now clear that, despite the clear mandate from . per cent of the British people that they want out, the painful preication of Mrs May’s “negotiations”has told the Brussels Eurocrats that our government is wavering on that mindset and, consequently, they feel they have us over an imported barrel.So it’s time to show them that they don’t — by openly preparing for no deal. After all, the notion that Merkel, Macron et al will bite off their own electorate’s noses to spite Britain’s volte face on EU membership is an absolute nonsense.In a letter to The Times yesterday, the chairman of pub chain JD Wetherspoon, Tim Martin, wrote: “The great urban myth, promoted by advocates of the deadly exchange rate mechanism, the euro and Remain, is that a ‘deal’ with the EU is a prerequisite of future prosperity.”The reality, he says, is that no deal would allow us to join successful countries such as Canada, Singapore, Israel and Australia in the free-trading world and “by slashing the EU’s , protectionist tarfs, shop prices will fall, with no loss to the Treasury, since tarf income is currently remitted to Brussels”.On top of that, we won’t have to pay the £billion orce bill, will regain control of our fishing waters, borders and laws and, ultimately, all have more money in our pockets. What’s not to love One expert from Economists for Free Trade did a few sums based on the boost in growthwe secure our financial and trading freedom against the impact of any no deal EU tarfs. The result  Calculated over ten years, the EU economy will lose by £billion while Britain’s will gain by more than £billion.Sweet as chocolate.A FAMILY in Caer-narfon, Gwynedd, is being allowed to continue covering their house in multi-coloured Christmas lights despite the complains of annoyed neighbours.Quite right too.I love it when people go all out with festive flamboyance.Just as long as they don’t live next to me.ASHLEY ROBERTS’ jive on Saturday’s Strictly  was indistinguishable from a professional.  And therein lies the problem.The original remit of this ratings juggernaut was that amateurs would be taught ballroom routines and morph before our eyes into graceful butterflies. Or, in John Sergeant and Ann Widdecombe’s case, common moths in freefall after a battering from a tea towel.But former Pussycat Doll Ashley is used to performing complicated dance routines in front of huge crowds and, therefore, oozed confidence and expertise from the get go.Little wonder since, according to her former dance teacher in the US, she was taught “all dferent styles of dance” from the age of eight to  and once had an introduction to ballroom training by an elite dance company at summer school.So yes, she’s undoubtedly the best, with former Steps trouper Faye Tozer not far behind. But the true Strictly stars are all the others who improve each week despite being way outside their comfort zone.FOLLOWING the shocking attack of a female PC being karate-kicked to the ground by a thug, the flippant commentary accompanying the footage is indeed sickening.But at least the film might help secure a prosecution and hopefully prove a turning point in how we take back control of our lawless streets.Because the real problem here is the fact that thugs clearly don’t fear the consequences of their actions.So may I humbly suggest that it’s high time the Home Office toughens up and shows, not tells, our hard-pressed police that they now have the power and support they need from on high to do their job effectively.CHECK out poo guru Gillian McKeith out on the town with her smiling -year-old daughter Skylar.Considering my daughters won’t be seen dead with meI wear anything more risqué than a baggy polo neck and tweed maxi skirt, she’s very fortunate indeed.THE £. Barbie Ultimate Kitchen has been named one of the top “must have” toys for Christmas, prompting criticism from those who think it panders to old-fashioned sexism.But one toy industry analyst counters: “She’s not just a housewe cooking for Ken. She’s watched The Great British Bake Off and she’s being innovative with her cooking.”Ever get the impression that the small kids being flogged this stuff are a darn sight brighter than the adults selling it BRITISH mother-of-four Becci Brennan has flown to the US to marry prisoner Travis Thompson, who has “hatred” tattooed on his forehead and is serving eight years for drug and gun offences.Of course she has.Let me guess – she’s going to be the one who changes him.MATTHEW CRAWFORD is st and blocking four beds in an NHS hospital because it can’t find a care home to take him.Probably because he also has convictions for attacking care home nurses and police and a racially aggravated assault. Nice.So far, his six-month stay at the Nottingham- shire-based hospital has cost the British taxpayer the princely sum of £,. Unsurprisingly, he’s on benefits, some of which he spends on “getting takeaways delivered” to his room.At what point does Matthew’s “human right” to gorge himself to such gargantuan proportions that he can barely move take second place to our right not to fund his gluttony and its resultant health issues ONE of supermarket Aldi’s advent calendars includes  bottles of wine for £.. And on the twelfth day of Christmas, my true love gave to me … a monster headache.SARAH FERGUSON has once again been waxing lyrical about how she and Prince Andrew are the “happiest orced couple” in the world.“We enjoy each other’s company, we allow each other to blossom,” she gushes.Are they – in the reverse spirit of Gwyneth and Chris – about to consciously recouple Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit bbc fact chuckers
story: We have no choice. In , we expect our national broadcaster to reflect all our opinions even-handedly.We don’t want the BBC to tell us that one side is right and the other wrong, or what we should believe, or which opinions are “true” and which are “”.But that is what the BBC has started to do, at least on the subject of Brexit.The BBC tried to be reasonably balanced during the referendum campaign, but it was so upset by the outcome that it has abandoned any attempt at impartiality and become grotesquely one-sided.The views of Remainers are not just over-represented, they are rarely challenged. And scare stories about Brexit which are either exaggerated or completely imaginary are presented as fact.I decided to compile a list of myths about Brexit — particularly scare stories about what will happen when we leave the Customs Union orwe leave Europe without a deal.Then I compared them with the facts. Although the pamphlet did not mention the BBC, most of the myths were things we hear daily on its programmes.The BBC rose to the bait and invited me into the Today programme on Radio  yesterday to be grilled by John Humphrys, its star interviewer. It was a fair enough interview. He challenged my arguments but I was able to refute his claims point by point.However, they then brought on a chap called Chris Morris, described as the BBC “reality checker”, who was invited to rebut my document. But all he did was oppose my facts with the opinions of people with whom he agreed.He systematically argued the Remain case and defended their Project Fear scare stories. The one thing he did not do was bring in any new facts. My central claim was thatwe leave the EU Customs Union but have a free trade agreement with the European Union, our businesses have little to fear.The main dference will be that traders will have to send in a customs declaration detailing the goods they are buying from or selling to Europe.That is a nuisance which we should try to simply as much as possible.But allegations that “this will be hugely costly, cause y delays, disrupt supply chains and undermine economic growth” are imaginary or exaggerated.“Fact checker” Morris said the majority of trade experts and freight companies to whom he had spoken robustly disagreed with me. This is an opinion, not a fact.Surely,trading in a free trade area — like that which exists between Switzerland and the EU or between Canada and the US — is so intolerable, the people there would be calling for a customs union.But they aren’t. I prefer their practical experience to the speculation of Mr Morris’s contacts.I also quoted a report by the CLECAT organisation, which covers , companies handling  per cent of the freight and customs in Europe, who said: “All the ingredients to ensure a smooth exit process of the UK from the EU, and which allow almost frictionless trade after the exit, are already available.”Why should a BBC fact checker’s unnamed contacts count for more than their considered view He then claimed there are no checks at the border at present. I go across to my house in France frequently and see the checks — for drugs, illegal immigrants, alcohol, cigarettes.And companies have to report all their cross-border trade separately on their VAT s and provide statistical s to Brussels.Then Mr Morris claimed there would be more checks by our customs officers at Dover, resulting in delays and disruption. That is nonsense.The Head of Customs and Revenue has said it only stops and searches lorries at present where it has intelligence information about drugs, illegal immigrants, and goods such as tobacco and alcohol, upon which excise duty is paid.It does not expect any of these risks to become more frequent. So it will not need to search any more vehicles.As I was still in the studio, I was able to rebut his pathetic attempts to rebut my facts. Normally he gets a clear run.But what is intolerable is that he almost never tries to rebut arguments by those trying to overturn the referendum result.I asked him afterwards to name a single Remainer whose case he had attempted to dissect. When he replied that there were “lots”, I said it should be easy to name one and, after repeated challenges, he named Jeremy Corbyn.The idea that Mr Corbyn — a man who has voted more often against European membership than any other MP and went on holiday during the referendum — is a Remainer could only be taken for reality by a BBC reality checker.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dup is not bluffing backstop
story: They want the Irish “backstop”, which weakens the Britain Northern Ireland union, binned. Or they’ll collapse the Tory Government their votes prop up.To the DUP the sanctity of the union is everything — far more fundamental even than keeping Corbyn, a notorious supporter of the IRA, and a united Ireland, out of Downing Street. Mrs May’s deal is an immediate threat.Corbyn can be fought later,he ever takes power. The Sun doesn’t see the DUP coming round. The PM must fix the backstop.No, the EU won’t play ball. But the deal is in disarray anyhow, here and in Brussels. Spain, France and Germany want it rewritten to punish us further. Others want more fishing rights. Our MPs won’t back it as it is, let alone an even harder version.But, that aside, Mrs May cannot govern at all without the DUP. And she must not try just to tough this out.She and Michel Barnier need solutions.WILL the Tories ever put the public health busybodies back in their box The fizzy drinks tax was just the start. As The Sun always predicted, they’re now after everything  . . . yoghurts, cereals, takeaways, you name it.They claim customers want the food industry to cut sugar — and that the Government must use “fiscal levers”needed to enforce it. That’s a weasel phrase meaning “new taxes consumers will end up paying”.Yes, obesity is a problem. But the reality of this demented war on the calories and sugar in our food supply — in place of educating Brits about diet and exercise — is blander grub or smaller portions . . . inevitably for the same price.Shoppers will then rightly turn on these same un-Conservative politicians and nanny-state meddlers who foolishly thought we were all onboard.WITH every utterance, Justice Secretary David Gauke makes his Government’s shambolic stance over the John Worboys parole scandal worse.There is no case for  members remaining anonymous. And to dismiss their role as “administrative” is crass.We still don’t know who decided to free the rapist, nor who rightly overturned that judgement. But we should.Parole  often make rulings with le-or-death implications for the ­public. They must be as accountable and identiable as any judge.Mr Gauke is normally one of the Government’s most unflappable performers. But, after first cravenly bottling out of a judicial review over Warboys’ parole, he is now championing secrecy.When in a hole, Mr Gauke, stop digging.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
