title: how vigilantes are taking streets back from machete gangs in town where cops do nothing
story: It came after a masked axeman had attacked a pregnant woman in a shop raid, and chilling footage emerged of a machete gang rampaging through the street.No-one was arrested for the attack on his pal and the gang attack footage shocked the nation. Enough was enough.Feeling West Midlands Police were doing little to help, he took to social media to encourage his community to police itself.Wayne says: “I wanted to set the group up because crime is getting out of hand, it’s running the area down.He was stunned when more than , members, all desperate to work together to keep each other safe, joined his online vigilante community - clearly the issue had struck a nerve.We Stand Together is one of a growing number of vigilante groups across the UK patrolling their own streets.Kingshurst residents Wayne, , and Tracy Quinn, , set up the group and now carry out twice-weekly patrols across the city - the Sun Online joined the pair on one this week.Were vigilantes with a twist, says Wayne.The group dont exact revenge or try and solve crimes. They patrol their area in high-vis jackets, knocking on residents and businesses doors proving reassurance.When Tracy and Wayne see a crime being committed, or the aftermath of a criminal activity, they alert the online community so anyone  local to that area can come out and assist.There is no law against the operation of vigilante groups - but police have warned that some techniques used, especially by paedophile hunting gangs, could cross into legally dangerous territory.They can tip off police to crimes being committed due to their network among the comunity, and could perform citizens arrests - but members of We Stand Determined say they would only do that in extreme circumstances.Due to a potential lack of legal training some evidence gathered by vigilante groups could actually damage any attempts at prosecution.In a judgement given at Newcastle Crown Court sparked by a paedophile hunter group, legal teams argued evidence gathered by them should be governed by the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act.However the judge in the case, Mr Justice Langstaff said there was no legal requirement for the group to be subject to controls, as they acted as private citizens.Police guidelines from the National Police Chief Council’s meeting in July of this year recommended police forces didn’t work with or endorse activities of vigilante groups.They then call the police and await their response – but admit in exceptional circumstances they will try to intervene and issue a citizen arrest.The areas they patrol include five crime hotspots – Smith’s Wood, Castle Bromwich, Kingshurst, Marston Green and Chelmsley Wood.In Smith’s Wood there is a rotation of seven officers and seven PCSOs on duty for the area, which at the last census in  had a population of ,.Between October  and September  a staggering . per cent of reported crime saw no further action taken. One person has been recorded as being sent to prison.In Chelmsley Wood, with a  population of , and patrolled by eight officers and four PCSOs, . per cent of crimes reported there have been shelved with no further action taken.Although the crime rate for Solihull is currently slightly lower than the average for other areas policed by West Midlands Police, data shows there has been a sharp rise in crime rates between September  and October .Last month a -year-old woman was set upon by three men after they broke into her house and stole her handbag.In recent weeks police have appealed for help with a suspected car burglary, an attempted break in, an attack on an Asda security guard and four arson attacks in these areas.Walking the streets of Birmingham, Wayne and Tracy seem unafraid of their surroundings, and are more concerned with knocking on doors to make sure residents felt safe.Ivan, who was checked in on by the pair, told us: “It’s a good thing to have people like this around. Usually we don’t open our door after tea time.“It’s nice to have good people out there.”One elderly man tells us the nights where he lives in Birmingham could be bad, but said his safety was increased with groups like We Stand Determined enforcing safety in that area.One worker for Norwich Express in Marston Green, who asked not to be named for fears over her safety, revealed just a week before men had come into the shop armed with guns demanding the till be emptied before they jetted away in a stolen car.And in a nearby Nisa Local shop, a member of staff claimed an unknown man who had been relentlessly shoplting over the last four weeks – with a lack of police action seemingly allowing him to walk away freely and pop back whenever he needed more.Kanlesh Patel says: “The police don’t want to know about anything under one hundred pounds worth of stuff.“They think it’s not worth pursuing. It’s getting worse because even the criminal knows these facts.“They’ll do it in front with you, with no shame.”Vigilante groups – once the staple of Wild West movies – are springing up as a response to the feral thugs causing widespread misery.“The police don’t do much, they pretend,” says one member of We Stand Determined.He adds ruefully: “The country has gone to heck in a hand basket.”Police guidelines from the National Police Chief Council’s meeting in July of this year recommended police forces didn’t work with or endorse activities of vigilante groups.We Stand Determined says it wants to work with police, but previously said the cops can only do what they can with the numbers they have – since  the West Midlands Police budget has been cut by £million and lost , officers.Documents from the council meeting stated “red lines” these groups could cross which would lessen their efforts, for example by making evidence unable to be used in court.But as officer numbers dwindle and cuts are made, members of We Stand Determined feel they have been forced to pitch in.Tracy and Wayne tell us due to Birmingham’s small, close-knit communities, victims often did not wish to reveal they had been affected by crime due to not wanting the attention, potentially leading to further ordeals.However Michael Bubb, a senior member of the group, reveals he joined after being the victim of a theft.He says: “A group of travellers jumped over my garden fence and stole items they could get too, I called the police and received a crime reference number but that’s all I received.”Now, with a huge influx in numbers, We Stand Determined hope to set up buddy systems for the elderly and self-defence classes for anyone who feels they need them.But Wayne and Tracy are not alone in their desperate quest for community-led justice.Residents of Hartlepool, County Durham, also carry out their own beats to deter burglaries and thefts after Cleveland Police suffered £million in cuts.There are now just  officers on duty overnight in the town, which has a population of ,, while their cars sit empty without enough officers to fill them.A BBC News investigation found that on a recent Saturday night, all  officers were dealing with incidents and there was no one left to handle emergency calls.Earlier this year we reported another group, dubbed the EssexAngels, set up a system to patrol their streets after police cuts left them feeling fearful of crime.And it was revealed all over the country desperate Brits have been paying as little as £-a-month for almost a quarter of a million private policemen to patrol the streets, tackling everything from race hate to stolen puppies.In September this year, officers had , crimes reported to them according to the latest statistics.The same statistic for September in  is ,.In , officers had , reports of crime in September.While in , they had , reported for the month.The crimes include anti-social behaviour, burglary, robbery, theft.West Midlands Police is the second largest police force in the UK, covering an area of  square miles.It serves a population of almost . million.Murder rates have soared by  per cent in the city this year, while the number of cases of possessing a kne jumped by almost  per cent to , last year.Its unemployment rates have risen to one of the highest in the UK, with some , people claiming benefits as of August .Councillor Mark Wilson, for Smith’s Wood, told Birmingham Live people were “losing confidence” in police presence.He said he was concerned “anything could happen” with groups taking on crime themselves, adding: “I think that is an issue … They could be the victims of assault or they could perpetrate an assault.”It comes after the city reeled after seeing recent footage of a seven-strong group armed with machetes attacking a victim in broad daylight and a clip of traffic warden beaten senseless by a gang of thugs horried global onlookers.Lancashire Chief Constable Andy Rhodes said this week during a debate on public involvement in crimes: “We are not saying to the public that we expect you to get involved in physical violence on the streets.“What we are saying is there are ways and means of helping us and some of the things that we are seeing are hindering us.“This isn’t a green light for have-a-go heroes.”During our time out and about on the streets, Wayne shares how his own criminal past led him to become so determined to transform his community.With a previous charge to his name for a theft in the year  and several other nights spent in custody, he is no longer a person of interest to police for any ongoing crime.Wayne says: “In my past, I have had good and bad times, in my youth I was in a bad place – which led be down paths better left unfollowed.“I know these instances in my past don’t look particularly good, but I want to reassure my group that in the past is where it stays.“I was in a dark space back then, but it has been nearly  years since I was charged with theft – In the now, I just want to help my community.”Affirming her support for both Wayne and the group, Tracy added: “Wayne has chosen to show and share his fallible side, but he’s changed his le for the good.“If all of us were held to every mistake we had made, none of would be anything.”West Midlands Police said they were aware of We Stand Determined and other vigilante groups in the area, but advised members to join police-approved Streetwatch programmes instead.

title: universal credit five week wait could be slashed amber rudd hints
story: When asked about whether she would cut the wait for new claimants, the DWP boss said she was looking at what we can do to get cash into peoples hands earlier.It comes after she promised to fix problems with the flagship benefits system and accepted there were areas in which it wasnt working.She told the BBC today that the biggest problem is getting cash into peoples hands as soon as they need it.Advance payments are available for Brits who cant wait five weeks for money, but that has to be paid back immediately out of their first UC sum.Ms Rudd said her department would make it clear to people they can get that upfront as soon as they apply and then pay it back over  months.On a damning report by a UN representative earlier this week, she promised to look at the concerns with women and single mums in particular.But she blasted the findings as being too political and implying the system was there to negatively impact Brits.The aim is to help people when they need it, and help them into work, she told Radio s Today programme.Our motives are to be efficient and compassionate.Ministers have already announced they will give an extra two weeks of several benefits to people on Universal Credit in future - but this wont come in until .At the moment people moving onto the new system get an extra two weeks of just housing benefit to help them cope with the switch.Ms Rudd insisted: The main message I want to give is that Universal Credit is a force for good and we will see how we can fix it.The new benefits system has been beset with issues since it first began being rolled out in .One chippy owner said yesterday the new system was pushing Brits AWAY from work as people couldnt figure out whether they would be better off or not.And earlier this week one desperate mum told how she was forced into sex work to get money for food after waiting for her first payment.One in six Brits still arent getting their first sum on time, the latest Universal Credit stats showed.MANY MPs can’t imagine being truly broke.We don’t mean a bit skint, having to max out the credit card or raid the savings account. We mean having literally no money and going hungry.So it is good to see Amber Rudd, in her first week as Work and Pensions Secretary, consider slashing the five-week wait many claimants endure before their Universal Credit comes through.We support the new benefits system. It is simpler and incentivises work.But that hold-up is unfair and causes real hardship. Sort it, Amber.

title: universal credit man live on pasta gravy mistake
story: Alun Krem-Szczesniak had hundreds of pounds cut from his payments because they wrongly believed he was getting carers allowance.The -year-old, from Pontardawe in Wales, said his experience with the new welfare system has been horrible and he was getting into debt because of errors the DWP made.Alun, who stopped working after contracting glandular fever, is entitled to £ a month, but for two months on the trot a mistake meant he only got half of that - £.The DWP told him it was because he was getting a carers allowance which knocked it down, but he hasnt been claiming that since his father died more than a year ago.He told Wales Online: It has been so humiliating - I have no pride left now. I shouldnt have to be begging people for money or for food.He went on: Friends and family have had to give me money - but I will still have to give them their money back.If it wasnt for them, I would be getting into more and more debt.But there are people that dont have friends or family they can turn to.I was going to my sisters house because I knew that I would have a cooked meal then.I dont think I would be hereit wasnt for the help I have had - I think I would have killed myself, or I would definitely have thought about it.There were times that I felt there was no way out. It has been horrible.Eventually Alun was paid the money he was owed, only for the same mistake to happen again the next month.He claims his landlord has been understanding about his late rent payments, but  bill companies are already chasing him for money.He already owes £ for his water, gas and electricity bills, and cant afford to start thinking about Christmas or even run his car.I have had to prioritise and a roof over my head is my first priority - I cant pay for my utilities at the moment so I dont have any choice but to ignore it, he said.I cant budget for anything - I cant buy any Christmas presents at the moment, it is a case of day to day living.A spokesman for the DWP said: “We have paid Mr Krem-Szczesniak the benefits due to him and we are contacting him to discuss his claim as a matter of urgency.We apologise for any inconvenience caused.”Universal Credit, which replaces six benefits with one, is being rolled out across the country - and will be in every area by the end of the year for new claimants.But its been beset with problems and Brits say its forcing them into debt and they never have any idea how much they will be getting.One single mum said she was forced to take £ for sex work just to make ends meet while she waited for her benefits to come through.The new DWP boss Amber Rudd has vowed to fix problems with the benefit system - and has even hinted she could slash the five week wait for payments.

title: universal credit keep benefits two weeks
story: And Brits who are already on the system shouldnt all have to make a fresh application or face getting their payments cut altogether, influential MPs on the Work and Pensions committee said.Ministers are considering how best to move millions of Brits from the old benefits system to the new one.They will vote within weeks on their rules on how best to do this - but some are calling for that vote to be delayed so theres enough time to fix vital issues.They said in a fresh report that there must be an additional two week payment for those on Universal Credit to help ease the pain. And they said there should be NO five-week wait for those who transfer over, and anyone who the DWP already have the information for should not have to apply again.At the moment Brits are entitled to two weeks of extra help with their housing payments, making the wait for their next sum effectively three weeks.Chancellor Philip Hammond revealed in the Budget that this will be extended to people on JSA and ESA - but not until .That still means anyone on tax credits wont get the extra two weeks of help.Committee chair Frank Field said of the Universal Credit changes: The Committee’s main proposals seek to ensure that the risk of moving claimants from the old system of benefits onto Universal Credit lies with the Government and not on the shoulders of poorer people.The Government is thankfully making and then remaking its policy on how best to transfer existing claimants onto Universal Credit.It would be a pitythe Government undermined this new way of thinking by not giving Parliament and SSAC enough time to comment on its latest changes before it pushes Parliament into a vote.The new system, which replaces six benefits with one, is being rolled out across the country - and will be in every area by the end of the year for new claimants.But its been beset with problems and Brits say its forcing them into debt and they never have any idea how much they will be getting.One single mum said she was forced to take £ for sex work just to make ends meet while she waited for her benefits to come through.The new DWP boss Amber Rudd has vowed to fix problems with the benefit system - and has even hinted she could slash the five week wait for payments.

title: toddler hair vaseline mum flour worse
story: Jaymielee Stewart, , was sent into a blind panic when three-year-old Lucas decided he wanted to style his hair for his first day of nursery - and used a whole tub of the gunk.Frantically looking at ways to get the slippery substance from his locks, she read that talcum powder would work, but as she didnt have any in the house used self-raising flour instead.The Vaseline and flour then combined to form a gooey paste and took hours of scrubbing, combing and washing to get out.It hadnt been a good week as it was, as this greasy gaffe came just a few days after the tot had grabbed some childrens scissors and cut a chunk out of his hair.Jaymielee knew something was wrong when she called Lucas for his breakfast and he was suspiciously quiet.He walked into the kitchen and proudly announced that he had done his hair.At first, she called her mum, Andrena, , who according to Jaymielee just laughed down the phone.She said: “Mum was no good, she was in stitches laughing.She got him in the shower but the water was just dripping back off his face due to the waterproof element of the product.I looked online and it suggested using talcum powder or baby powder, I didn’t have either but was trying to think of something similar.“I knew I had self-raising flour so ran to get it. I tried to rub it in but it just looked like I was baking a cake on his head.“I hoped it would absorb it but it made a paste, it was like the episode with Ross from Friends with the leather trousers.“I rinsed that out and saw someone  had posted about using a deep-cleansing soap. I didn’t have that but I did have soap powder so I stuck about half a box on his head and kept washing it.“In total, I washed his hair  times.“I have used every single bottle of shampoo, two bottles of conditioner, half a bag of self-raising flour, half a box of soap powder and cornflour.“I’ve managed to get most of it out with the shampoo and combing but it’s still very greasy.“I’ll just have to hope it rains on the nursery run so I can get away with him wearing a hat and explain to the nursery teachers what’s happened.“He’ll have to go to nursery looking like a little grease ball.”

title: lad who raised 300 on gofundme for tenerife holiday called a scrounger by this morning viewers but he insists its not begging
story: He launched the fundraising campaign after writing on Facebook that he was sick of people on benefits being able to go abroad and I cant.The ITV show was hosting a debate on whether or not crowdfunding is a modern form of begging after a dad from Hull was given £, in donations so he could purchase his kids presents.Defending his GoFundMe venture, Aiden said: I put a status on Facebook to say why can people on benefits afford to go on holiday and I cant afford a night out in my local town .People commented getting their back up about it, and someone commented again why dont you get a crowdfunding going so thats what I did and I raised about £.I went to Tenere. It was great.While he says it is just a bit of fun, some friends did not see it that way.One said: You scrounger, save up like other people anda holiday is that important to you fund it yourself.A supporter who donated £ wrote: Proper made me smile this, good on ya. I hope you raise your target.However he managed to reach the sum of £ and today he told how he enjoyed his trip.After appearing on the show, social media users hit out at crowdfunding and have insisted it is begging.One wrote: For treatments illnesses to help desperate times yes. For luxury items surgery holidays absolutely not! If you havent got it, earn it!Another posted: Ive crowdfunded to raise money for a  year old women with breast cancer and five kids and that money was to be used to give those kids memories with their mother.But for Christmas presents  No way!Others said it was embarrassing.Speaking to The Sun Online at the time he launched the GoFundMe, Mr Dugdale said: It started off as a joke.I thought I’d set up the fundraising page, and ended up with a grand total of £, buta free holiday comes up.. I’m ready.My mates all laugh about it, it’s the first thing that gets said to me when I see them.I’ve never actually been abroad, soI raise enough money I’d go Spain.

title: eerie images spot lurking background
story: You may even question the sanity of those posing for their photographs, with one mum clearly unable to feel whats underneath her.A group of musicians pose for a pic with their instruments, in an apparent bid to show who has the best keyboard or electric guitar.But one smug music fan lying in front of them, goes completely unnoticed as he flashes his open briefcase while holding onto a gun.Another frightening snap shows a man smiling for a selfie next to a cheery woman, but in her reflection behind her theres a face in the back of her head.Have a look over these and other spooky snaps...

title: let kids climb trees instead of just doing maths homework claims education secretary
story: Education Secretary Damian Hinds will publish a series of extra-curricular goals for pupils to achieve every year - which could include cooking on campfires, knitting and growing vegetables - in order to toughen them up.He said: “Bluntly, it is about doing stuff that doesn’t involve looking at a screen. It’s about getting out and about.”Mr Hinds said he recognised formal qualications “are obviously not the only thing.He said it was important to teach children how to “bounce back from the knocks that inevitably come to all of us”.He added: “We put a lot effort into making sure we can share really good curriculum plans and teaching materials.“This is an equivalent of that for stuff outside the curriculum, in recognition of the fact that what you do academically is only part of the story.”The Education Secretary came across the idea on a visit to St Werburgh’s Primary School in Bristol, where pupils are given a “passport” of enrichment activities.Between arrival in reception and leaving in year six youngsters are given  goals to achieve each year.It includes visiting a place of worship, baking a cake and tracking wild animals.The school’s list is based on the National Trust’s “ things to do before you’re  and three-quarters” initiative.WE heartily approve of primary kids being tasked with damming streams, canoeing and playing conkers.Sure, it’s a bit Swallows And Amazons. And a big ask in Moss Side or Tower Hamlets. But children do spend far too much time gawping at screens.Education Secretary Damian Hinds wants that to change. All power to him.

title: hugh hefner boudoir playboy sale
story: Images of his bedroom, where he entertained three wives and dozens of Playboy bunnies, revealed Betty Boo statues, monsters heads, and many images of himself with women.Among the lots is an eight inch tall vintage ceramic ashtray of a female nude, valued at £-.A selection of his captain’s hats is up for sale for between -£.His signature silk smoking jacket is expected to reach between £,-£,.Auctioneers Julien’s hoped Hefner’s style will be a hit, and nothing sums up his singular taste like a fishnet-stockinged lamp with a fringed shade.Furniture includes a carved oak chair valued at £-, and a tiger print sofa, valued at over £,.One of items likely to fetch the highest dollar is Hefners first edition copy of Playboy magazine.The copy was discovered earlier this month after  years and is set to make over £, for charity.It cost just  cent to buy at the time and boasts on the cover that the publication offers the famous Marilyn Monroe nude in full colour.The  publication, which famously featured Marilyn Monroe on the cover, has recently been unearthed by Hefner’s children, who decided to sell the rare magazine along with a number of his other possessions to raise money for charity.Daughter Christie Hefner said: “Whether it was building his company into one of the most recognizable global brands in history or standing up for social, sexual and civil rights causes, my father lived an extraordinary le as a publishing, social and cultural pioneer.”The edition completely sold out at the time and went on to sell more than , copies.Hefner died age  last September.Hefners complete personal set of bound Playboy volumes is anticipated to be the most lucrative sale, with estimates at £,.Hefner, who was extremely well read, also owned a first edition copy of F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby and large folio volumes of Slavador Dalis Biblia Sacra, worth more than £,.The auction will take place on November  and December  in Los Angeles.

title: city worker turns horse box cabin van travel world cosy
story: The converted horse box boasts beautul upholstery, stunning Douglas fir woodwork and a panoramic window next to a cosy dinner table.Incredibly the stunning mobile home also has all mod cons - with an indoor cinema, full-size cooker, shower, spacious fridge and a fully-upholstered sofa.The spacious xft Mercedes -D cost just £, to buy and convert- half the price of a parking space in Londons posh Barbican Estate.It was lovingly crafted by Guy Williams, , who hit the road after becoming disaffected with a -year career in surveying before he moved into hotel management.After a pay-out from his last job he bought and converted the van in just a year and is now travelling across Europe with his -month-old Cockapoo puppy Ethel.Mr Williams, who is currently in Portugal, said: Basically I was sick of it.I used to be a charted surveyor in Bristol and I quit that because I didnt want to be in a   everyday until I was .I looked around me and all the people there were rotting behind their desks.I left and I started living in my other van and rented out my flat in Bristol and I was earning more money doing that than I was surveying.He added: After doing that for a while I wanted to do something a bit bigger and I ended up buying this horse box from Holland and driving it back.I kitted it out with the intention of living in it, I did it over a year but I reckon I couldve done it in just two months.We were going for a log-cabin style and we were inspired by the Alps - it is basically a log cabin in a van.It is more kitted out than a lot of flats, it has everything I need.This is a house on wheels and it cost just £, and you can park up anywhere.You cant even put a deposit down for that.After finishing building the van earlier this year Mr Williams set off in early September - with plans afoot to head to Morocco and finish up by celebrating his birthday in the Alps.When his trip is over the intrepid explorer plans to refurbish vans into homes after his unusual home sparked interest in the UK.Several conversions have been lined up and he will take them on after ing in Spring.He said: Im not doing the conversions to make loads of money Im doing them because I enjoy it.Back in the day people would call you a crustyyou live in the back of a van and people would look down their noses at you, but now it is cool to live in a van.It is not mainstream, but it is not to rebel - it is free living and you are off grid.All you need is your fuel and cost of the food, there is no worries of paying bills or a red letter.Van le is so cheap and you have the bonus of being able to go anywhere you want to go and you have everything you need in a box.

title: britain worst female paedo disguise identity
story: Vanessa George earned the grisly title in  after she was caged for taking  pictures of herself harming babies and toddlers at a nursery she worked at.George is now eligible for parole and a hearing is expected early next year - meaning she could be back on the streets next month, Plymouth Herald reports.The newspaper says she has changed her name while in prison - reverting to her maiden name of Vanessa Sylvia Marks.She is planning to follow in the footsteps of Tracy Lyons - one of the four members of the paedophile ring led by Georges online lover Colin Blanchard.Lyons, who was jailed in  for sending sickening child abuse pictures to Blanchard, changed her name after she released just nine months later.Georges change comes after she orced husband Andrew, who has said he would jump for joyshe killed herself.The mum-of-two described herself to Blanchard as a paedo whore mum in vile exchanges between the two.She worked at Little Teds nursery in Efford, Plymouth, where she sexually assaulted a number of children in her care and sent indecent images to her lover.George admitted to a total of seven sexual assaults of young children and six counts of distributing and making indecent pictures of children.She was sentenced to seven years Blanchards other online lover, ex-prostitute Angela Allen.Tracy Dawber, who was in a year-long relationship with the paedo ringleader, was caged for four years for abusing a two-year-old boy and letting Blanchard film it.Blanchard - described as the hub of the paedophile wheel at his sentencing - was given a minimum term of nine years in .

title: gay athlete disowned family picture girlfriend
story: Emily Scheck, , found all her childhood belongings including awards, plaques and stuffed animals taken from her family home and dumped in her car by her parents.Her le was turned upside down when her mother found a picture of the girl she was dating, Outsports reported.After refusing to undergo conversion therapy, her parents said she was never to speak to them or her siblings again.“I really didn’t know how someone should respond to that,” Scheck told Outsports.The talented cross-country runner is currently studying at Canisius College in Buffalo, New York State and was left with just  to her name.The licence plates of the car she saved up to buy were removed by her father, who had driven to Buffalo from their home near Rochester, after her parents stopped paying the insurance.With the two jobs she has both paying every two weeks, she relied on her friends and girlfriend to get by, as she was about to start her pre-season sports training.She said: “At the start it was definitely tough. I was lucky to be in pre-season the first couple of weeks because coach could get us meals in the dining hall.”Emily is on a sports scholarship that covered some of fees at the college but it was still a long way off what she needed to keep studying.Her coaches tried to help while a friend and teammate Grace Hausladen set up a GoFundMe page with the initial aim of raising , .Thanks to hundreds of kindhearted strangers, it has raised over , .But initially she was told by the university that accepting the donation was in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules on accepting gts.After an appeal, though, the NCAA reversed that decision and she will be allowed to keep the money.In a statement the college said: “NCAA rules allow a school to assist a student-athlete with a fundraiser after a signicant le event occurs.“Canisius and the NCAA will continue to work together in support of Emily.“She is a member of the Canisius family and we will to do whatever we can to assist her.”

title: jacob rees mogg says he wont stand to replace theresa may as feuding tory brexiteers turn on each other after coup flop
story: The top Brexiteer joked thathe put his hat in the ring it would be thrown back at him like Bond villain Oddjob.And he suggested that Boris would make a better PM because he makes politics interesting and has the qualities of leadership.Mr Rees-Moggs comments came as his allies in the European Research Group turned on each other in the wake of the failed coup against the PM.Writing in the Spectator, Mr Rees-Mogg defended his decision to call for a vote of no confidence in Mrs May.He admitted: It was naive of me to expect the Prime Minister to change her policy. It is not how it works - the wrong policy means the wrong person.But he added: If there were a leadership election, which I hope there will be, I would not throw my hat into the ring as I fear it would be thrown back ‘Oddjob’ style.The ERG chair hinted he would end up supporting Boris, saying that Tory activists are enthusiastic about the prospect of the ex-Foreign Secretary taking power.Mr Rees-Mogg wrote: He certainly makes politics interesting and has the qualities of leadership.A week ago today, the leading Brexiteer announced he had sent a letter to backbench chief Sir Graham Brady calling for Mrs May to go.But the revelation failed to spark the expected cascade of letters which would have forced a vote of confidence in the PM.Last night, ERG member Nadine Dorries blasted her Brexiteer allies who failed to join the revolt against Mrs May.In a furious WhatsApp message leaked to the Guido Fawkes website, she wrote: There are a handful of you who have badly let the ERG down as a group, opening us up to ridicule and abuse in the media and online.I am referring to those MPs who have not put their letters in.It is being said that you have let the side down and are not the type of people anyone would want to go into battle with.The Brexiteer rebels are now pinning their hopes on a fresh push for a leadership challenge next month, after the PMs deal is voted on by MPs.BORIS Johnson earned almost £ a minute giving a speech to a finance firm in New York, it emerged last night.The former Foreign Secretary raked in a staggering £, for the two hour talk which comes on top of his £, a month salary for a Dailycolumn and his £, a year MP’s salary.He was addressing the US Golden Tree Asset Management firm in the Big Apple earlier this month.Mr Johnson also took in a £, donation for his office and staffing costs.And he pocketed a further £, in royalties from his books.The figures came from the MP’s official register of interests.

title: woman lifelike dolls prams
story: Holly Smith, , and fiance Adam Taylor, , take the three dolls on walks every day - spending all their spare money dressing them in second-hand clothes.The dolls are so realistic that a bus driver once stuck up for Holly when another mum tried to force her out of a parking spot.Her fixation with the dolls - known as reborns - began last year when she and Adam started struggling to conceive.She was also left shattered after losing a pregnancy at  weeks in .Holly, from Romford, Essex, said: I have three reborns - Christopher, a six-month-old baby, and Lola and Logan are twins. Theyre newborn babies.I take them out in the pram everywhere I go. I just feel normal and like a mother.People think theyre real babies and when I tell them the truth, theyre so shocked as they look so realistic.People have said they are so beautul and look so real. Ive had people hold them because they dont believe theyre not real babies.In the past, I have had a couple of negative comments but its more to do with taking up pram space on the bus than the actual doll.When Ive been on the bus, people have said move your pram, your baby is not real. Its just a doll.Once, the bus driver was even on my side because I was there first and they just think its a sleeping baby. Theyve said I need to be put in a crazy home.They help me to be a mother like I dream of every day.In , I lost a baby and I was heartbroken.I had the miscarriage and felt lost and alone. I was so depressed I didnt know what to do with myself and cried for months.Picking up the reborn babies helps a lot. It just melts your anxiety away.These dolls gave me something to look forward for another day.Theyre the reason I get up in the morning with a smile on my face.I treat them like real babies but I know theyre not real. They just mean so much to me as a real baby would.

title: punter suing betfred refusing payout
story: Andrew Green, , splashed out while celebrating after becoming a millionaire playing a blackjack game on Betfreds website.But five days later the bookie told him he would not be receiving the cash because there had been a software mal.The dad-of-two turned down a £, settlement, which required a nondisclosure agreement and is now fighting his case in the High Court.He told BBC News: They [Betfred] are quick to take peoples money but when it comes to paying out they offered money as a gagging agreement.How many are there out there who have signed similar agreements Andrew said: Ive been bullied. Im just a fish in a big sea and they are a great big shark but Im not going to be forced away just because they are worth billions and Im not.Eventhere was a glitch I did nothing wrong. I played that game and pressed a button.Back in January Andrew, of Washingborough, Lincolnshire, started playing Frankie Dettoris Magic Seven with a £ stake.He lost almost all of his money to the online game but managed to work his way up from £ to £,.But one final play won him the £. million jackpot.Jubilant Andrew spent £ as he toasted his new-found fortune down the pub.But Betfred later voided the win, claiming there was a glitch in the new game release.Peter Coyle, Andrews solicitor, claims the company has refused repeated requests to provide evidence of the computer problem.A preliminary High Court hearing was told this week the company did not have the game data and so could not force the game developer to hand it over.A spokesman for Betfred said: Betfred loves to pay out all our jackpot winners, both big and small.Unfortunately, and as Mr Green is aware, a new game release suffered a software mal in January this year and no legitimate jackpot win occurred.Given that Mr Green is currently exploring his legal options, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further.In , Betfred was forced to remove a slot game from their site after a punter was ly told he won £,.Jamie Gardiner, from Kirkby, Liverpool, was playing the “Land of Gold” game when he got three clovers.A pop up then appeared saying “Win: £,.”.The -year-old was over the moon but soon become concerned when the cash was not credited to his online Betfred account. Mr Gardiner said hed won money in the same way before before, but Betfred insisted it wasnt legitimate.   At the time, he said: I play all the time and I know when it comes up there it is meant to go straight into your balance.“I got two mushrooms and three clovers and whenever you get three clovers you are credited with the jackpot.”

title: stalker partner love contract marry
story: Lina Tantash, , drove college tutor Jarlath Rice, , to the brink of suicide bombarding him with emails and calls and harassing his colleagues.The pair met while working in Dublin in  and had a fling which lasted less than a month.When Mr Rice broke off the sexual relationship with the increasingly-demanding Tantash, she ordered him to sign a -caluse “love contract” while claiming he owed her £,.The bizarre agreement stipulated he should stop denying they were in a relationship despite the Irishman telling her to stop contacting him.It also stated he should live with her three days a week, speak to her on the phone for at least  minutes every evening and be nice to her.She even hired a private detective to hunt him down, look into his private le and obtain his contact details.Jordanian-born Tantash was sentenced to four years in prison today after she was convicted of two counts of stalking.As she was sentenced her mother broke down in court and begged the judge for mercy for her daughter.Lewes Crown Court heard the extraordinary saga began in  when the “highly intelligent” university-educated project manager met Mr Rice, an Irish filmmaker, when they were both working in Dublin in .After Tantash began harassing him, Mr Rice fled to Brighton, East Sussex, where he started work as a college tutor.But the stalker, then a “highly-respected” project manager at prestigious Trinity College Dublin, followed him taking up a new role in London.Her campaign of harassment escalated after she suspected Mr Rice, who was working as a tutor at DV College in Brighton, had started a relationship with work colleague, Sarah Bolland.She began bombarding Miss Bolland with abusive phone calls and emails at the college demanding she stop seeing Mr Rice.Miss Bolland, who was not romantically involved with Mr Rice, was devastated by the abusive calls.On one occasion Tantash called her and said: “Stay away from him, whore! Stay away from Jarlath, bitch. I’m going to f******g kill you.”On another she said “You don’t see him, you don’t date him and don’t f**k him. I’ll kill myself. Would you rather have my blood on your hands ”And in another Tantash was recorded saying: “You look like a horse and you’re an ugly f******g bitch.”In an email to her she told Miss Bolland she had “disgusting frizzy hair, skin like curdled yoghurt and buck teeth” and that she hoped she had a “heartbroken, horrid end”.Tantash also sent abusive emails from several anonymous accounts to friends, family and work colleagues demanding Mr Rice’s mobile number, his home address and other details.She bombarded one colleague with  phone calls in one evening asking that he hand over Mr Rice’s mobile phone number and even offered him £, for the information.On the evening of an open night at DV College Tantash ordered around £ of takeaway pizzas and had them delivered to the college.She was eventually arrested and charged with one count of stalking Mr Rice between July  - February  and one count of stalking Miss Bolland. She was convicted after a trial at Brighton Magistrates Court.In a victim impact statement Mr Rice said the campaign of stalking left him on the brink of suicide and had been in “despair”.He said: “For over  years I’ve had to live with verbal, mental and physical abuse.“The aggressive and abusive dismantling of my le has left me vulnerable, frightened and exhausted.”Mr Rice said he had been “pushed deep into depression” adding: “At my worst I have gone through periods of despair with suicide ideation.”In her defence, Tantash said she came from a stable, upper middle class family but was suffering from a mental condition.She claimed to have paid Mr Rice’s sizeable debts and supported his career infor a romantic commitment.Miss Bolland said: “It’s a strange and terrible experience when someone psychologically harasses you like this.“It’s an awful feeling. It’s astonishing how much it can impact your le, your mood, your thoughts.”Teresa Mulrooney, defending, said: “Miss Tantash deeply regrets her behaviour and has come to understand the impact it has had.”Sentencing her, Recorder Stephen Lennard, said: “You were never prepared to accept it was over and thereafter carried out a sustained and vicious campaign of stalking and harassment that lasted  years.“In my opinion you are vicious, devious and manipulative woman. You should be thoroughly ashamed of what you have done to Mr Rice and Miss Bolland.”He also handed her a restraining order.

title: amazon black friday store queues
story: Despite the bitter cold, scores of keen buyers have been spotted standing patiently in line outside the pop-up store in Shoreditch High Street.Amazon said its popular “pop-up is back and jam-packed with even more entertainment to celebrate the UK’s biggest annual deals event, and the start of the Christmas shopping season.”Its “biggest ever” Black Friday sale started after midday today, with thousands of deals across every department to kick-off the Christmas season.Trying to entice as many shoppers as possible, the retail giant said the store is “set to showcase the very best of Black Friday at Amazon, from great deals on must-have products to fast delivery and fun, innovative shopping experiences.“This year there will be even more prize giveaways, workshops, VIP experiences, and product sampling, offering something for all the family.”The retailer adds that “there will also be chances to experience the latest range of Amazon devices” as customers will be able to “explore unique products from start-ups with Amazon Launchpad and much more.Visitors can take part in workshops, ranging from cocktail-making masterclasses, to jewellery and candle-making sessions, beauty treatments and hair styling from celebrity hairstylist Nicky Clarke.There will also be cooking demos at the store, which is open  hours on Friday.Big brands showcasing deals, experiences or offering prize giveaways include Whole Foods Market, HP, Samsung, LEGO, Xbox, Le Creuset, Yankee Candle, Sennheiser, Canon and Nescafe Dolce Gusto.The pop-up, which opened its doors at .pm today, runs until pm Sunday, November .Shoppers throughout Britain are expected to spend about £.million per minute on Black Friday itself.With all thoughts of frugality out the door, shoppers have been quick to mock themselves on social media ahead of the official spend-a-thon.Brits have been sharing tweets and memes about their purchases and referring to their rapidly disappearing bank balances ahead of the big sales weekend.There are also charities hoping to take advantage of big-spending Brits, to help their cause.Britain leads the way on Black Friday and Cyber Monday spending - with more UK consumers grabbing deals than anywhere  in the world.An international survey found our shoppers spend more, on average £ , during the long sale weekend than any other country.The next big-spending rival was the US, where on average consumers will spend  €each.However, the Press Association reports that Black Friday spending is expected to dip for the first time since its arrival in the UK as retailers brace for the start of a fiercely competitive Christmas trading period.Consumers will spend £. billion on deals in stores and online, down from last years £. billion, according to the predictions from the Centre for Retail Researchand VoucherCodes.Yet spending across the weekend, including Cyber Monday, is expected to be up . per cent on last year to £. billion.Just over a quarter of Britonsfeel positive about Black Friday, with almost a third of consumersplanning to buy clothing, footwear or accessories on Friday,  per cent being in the market for gadgets and home technology, and  per cent expecting to buy toys.Consumer watchdog Which  found that nearly nine in  deals available last year had been cheaper at other times.Which  tracked the prices of  products, including TVs, cameras and fitness trackers, on offer over Black Friday  from six months before until six months afterwards, finding that  per cent of the items were cheaper at other times of year and nearly half were cheaper in the six months after Black Friday.Analyst Springboard said it expected the sales event to do very little to help the high street, anticipating Black Friday footfall would be down . per cent compared with last year and . per cent lower over the weekend as a whole, and predicting online transactions will be down  per cent on last year.

title: four lions freedom from circus south africa game reserve
story: Campaigner Lionel De Lange, , raised £, to take them to the Kragga Kamma Game Reserve.Along the way people from around the world came together to try and help by buying T-shirts, prints and pledging donations.After a massive -hour journey from crate to enclosure, and by road and air, the mighty predators are now finally safe in South Africa.Lioness twins Charlie and Kai, four, and their younger sister Luca, aged three, have only ever known bars and cages since being born into the circus.And just a year ago the girls were joined by Nathan, then a tiny lion cub, who also faced a sad le being kept for entertainment.Lionel said: “Six weeks ago, I didn’t think we’d get this far, and six months ago I didn’t think we’d make it, but we have.He continued: “For now the future for these four lions is to be what they were born to be, just lions, lie around in the sun, get fed and just relax… and not have to live in their own urine and faeces.“It was a hard trip but the vet checked them over and once the anaesthetic wore off they were ready.At the South African game reserve the lions now have an amazing , square metres of lush African bush, compared to before being rescued when the girls shared a cage of just  square metres.Lionel, who travelled down with his we Anya and Ukrainian vet Mikhail, said of the lions first steps on African soil: “It was at .am this morning, under an African sky and after a breakfast of impala. It was unbelievable, I almost can’t put it into words.Lionel said the rescue of the lions was only possible thanks to the amazing generosity and donations from iniduals, sponsors and companies around the world.He added: All over the world people have banded together to give big donations, small donations, everyone has worked together.The effort has been a roaring success.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bungle chow chow freed sun campaign
story: The fluffy puppy was allowed home after more than , supporters backed a petition demanding his release.Four-month-old Bungle was detained under the Dangerous Dogs Act for giving a cop a minor nip after running loose.He faced being held up to nine months in secret kennels.But in a victory for “common sense” Northamptonshire Police contacted the pet’s owners saying they had “reviewed” the situation.They claimed “Bungle had calmed down” and felt it was best he was back with bankers David Hayes, , and we Susan, , and their -year-old son Joseph.Delighted Joseph cuddled the cherished pet he feared he would not see at Christmas.In a statement, the relieved family said: “A very understanding police officer brought Bungle home to us.Bungle was SSSOOOO pleased to see us and excited, it was lovely.”Earlier a police source said: “The public reaction has been mad.”The Sun’s front page story on Wednesday highlighted Bungle’s plight.The £, pup rushed out of the drive to the family’s £million home on Saturday before the electric gates could shut.He was found nearby cowering under a lorry on the A near Towcester, Northants.Frightened Bungle twice nipped a cop who stopped to grab him — on the hand and arm.Under the Act, he could be destroyed and his owners fined and jailedconvicted.No decision on any prosecution has been made.Police said the owners agreed to a Voluntary Control Order which means they must ensure their pet remains under control at all times.Chief Supt Chris Hillery said: “Having gone through a proportionate investigation and risk assessment, the dog has been ed with appropriate conditions to manage any future risk.The officer who was bitten is recovering well.”Zaneta Mlynek, , who owns Bungle’s mother Tosca, insisted: “Bungle is soft natured.He was the shyest pup of the litter.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: salisbury novichok suspects lexander petrov and ruslan boshirov cctv
story: Detectives have also released pictures of a specially made perfume bottle they are alleged to have carried the deadly nerve agent in.Footage of the two suspects – known by aliases Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov – shows them as they arrive and travel around Salisbury on Sunday  March.It is claimed the men are on the way to the home of Sergei Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, who were found seriously ill on a bench that afternoon.Officers want to speak to anyone who saw them between - March, or anyone who may have seen the counterfeit ‘Nina Ricci’ perfume box.It was eventually recovered from poisoned Charlie Rowley’s address in Muggleton Road in July, killing Dawn Sturgess after she sprayed the substance on her arm.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Dean Haydon said: “We remain as determined as ever to identy and bring to justice all those responsible for the reckless acts that left four people critically ill and, tragically, saw Dawn Sturgess lose her le.“We are progressing a number of active lines of enquiry but one of the key things we are still to identy is where the counterfeit perfume bottle was between the time we think it was discarded on the afternoon of  March, to when Charlie Rowley says he found it on  June.The first CCTV clip shows the two suspects as they arrive at Salisbury train station on Sunday  March at around .am.The second clip shows the suspects at approximately .am walking past a petrol station in Wilton Road, which is in the vicinity of the Skripals’ home address.This is just prior to when detectives believe the nerve agent was placed on the door handle.The third clip shows the two men walking over a bridge on Fisherton Street at approximately pm before they eventuallyto Salisbury train station and travel back to Heathrow.They then catch a flight to Moscow later that night.As Assistant Commissioner Neil Basu stated that, although unlikely, it is impossible to guarantee that there are no other materials present in the Salisbury area.He warned people not to pick up random or suspicious items in the area.He added: The amount that was in the bottle and the way it was applied to the Skripals home address was completely reckless.Dep Asst Commissioner Dean Haydon, who led the probe into the March attack, called it “completely reckless”.Asked how many more people it could have killed, Mr Haydon said: “Possibly into the thousands. The amount in the bottle and the way it was applied.Boshirov, one of two thugs believed to have been behind the nerve agent attack in Salisbury in March, was given the Hero of the Russian Federation medal in  - a decoration reportedly handed out by Putin himself, claims the report by Bellingcat.Last month, Russia again insisted the Salisbury assassins are INNOCENT despite one of them being unmasked as high-ranking spy decorated by Putin himself.

title: temple discovery kuwait 7500 year old
story: Archaeologists working at site in Kuwait have discovered a new temple and public plaza that suggest an advanced society.The Ubaids, of which little is known, were the first agricultural settlers to move into the region which would later become Sumer in the southernmost region of ancient Mesopotamia.The ancient culture is characterised by large village settlements, with sophisticated irrigation techniques and the appearance of the first temples.Headed by Professor Piotr Bielinski of the Polish Centre of Mediterranean Archaeologyat the University of Warsaw, the dig also included the Kuwaiti archaeologists Sultan al-Duweish and Hamid al-Mutairi.Professor Bielinski said: Indications suggest that it was a building with a cultic and it combines elements of the Ubaid culture.Further research may prove that the building is the oldest of its kind, not only in Kuwait but also in the whole Persian Gulf region.A large space between the buildings was also reported, something Mr Bielinski identied as a plaza or village square and indicates town planning, which is very surprising at a site with such an early date.Furthermore, at least  other structures and , pottery fragments were discovered at Bahra  since work began in .Bahra  is the largest Ubaid settlement found on the Arabian Peninsula.It is believed that the mysterious culture led to the creation of the regions first cities and boasted a complex social structure which is still being researched by archaeologists.

title: abusive boyfriend girlfriend too strong
story: Paul Measor, , subjected former partner Lauren Smith, , to daily abuse and even trained their one-year-old son to call her a s**g and a s**t.She recorded his vile outbursts - which included him spitting in her face - which were played to the court.He was convicted of common assault and jailed for five months - but he was cleared of the offence of using controlling and coercive behaviour.District Judge Helen Cousins said she had to decide whether his behaviour had a serious effect on the victim.She said the behaviour was disgraceful but didnt have a big enough impact on Lauren to find him guilty.Schools learning manager Lauren hit back: It has had a serious effect.Im attending meetings with a domestic violence support group, my confidence has been badly knocked and I struggle to trust people.He controlled my le for four years and the effect of that didnt go away the minute he was taken away by the police. It still hasnt, its going to take time.She said that his forthcoming appeal will drag up the same issues.Lauren added: It doesnt matter whether a woman is considered strong and capable or not,they are subjected to that kind of behaviour it surely goes without saying that its had a serious effect on them.Katie Ghose, Chief Executive of Women’s Aid, said: “No judge should base their judgement of a domestic abuse-related case on whether the victim matches their stereotype of what a victim should look or act like.Coercive and controlling behaviour is at the heart of domestic abuse and has a long-lasting and devastating impact on the survivor.Danielle Chadwick, of Hartlepool-based anti-domestic violence group Harbour, added: “We want victims to feel able to come forwardthey are experiencing this kind of abuse.During the trial Lauren said that Measor, who ran his own maintenance company, tracked her movements whenever she went out using an app.She had to send him Snapchats to prove she was at certain places and knew her phone and social media passwords.In a recording played to court the couples young son can be heard being told to tell her to f*** off.Judge Cousins said: I have to be satisfied the behaviour was controlling, coercive, and it had a serious effect on the victim.Theres no doubt the victim is a strong and capable woman, whose evidence was truthful.She has since successfully removed herself from the harmful situation.

title: yakutsk siberia coldest city tips
story: Two minutes later tiny icy daggers needled my nose, cheeks, ears and any other flesh foolishly left exposed as I walked through the sub-zero city square.Five more minutes and a numbness began penetrating the soles of my thick-soled boots and insulated gloves until the ends of my fingers and toes throbbed and ached.And ten minutes later I found myself desperately seeking refuge as super-cooled air glued my glasses to my face and began freezing my eyeballs.The Sun yesterday ventured to the frosted lair of the Beast from the East — the source of this week’s first blast of winter weather to hit Britain.Yakutsk,  miles from the Arctic Circle, is home to , hardy souls. Bone-chilling winds from the vast wastes surrounding this city travel , miles to give Britain its most extreme winter weather.It was -C in Yakutsk yesterday — and tough locals couldn’t believe -C winds had brought swathes of Britain to a shivering standstill this week.Oxana — snug in a full- sable fur coat and with her condensed breath frozen on the collar — said: “This is almost T-shirt weather for us. I find it hard to believe a few degrees below freezing causes so much chaos in England. In Yakutsk, everything works normally at -.”Receptionist Valeria Lyakhov, , said: “When the temperature drops below - you have to take care to protect every part of your body from the cold. It’s possible to get frostbite crossing the street. I’ve felt my nose and eyeballs freezing in extreme conditions.”No railway reaches the city and travel options are limited to flying — a terryingly short, bumpy, frozen runway where passengers escaped a crash drama in October — or a ,-mile highway built by Stalin slaves dubbed “The Road of Bones”.Every building in Yakutsk, which has summer temperatures as high as C , is built on stilts sunk into the permafrost.Heavily insulated pipework for water supplies and heating is also elevated above the frozen ground, creating crazy steaming tangles dubbed “the guts” of the city.Official cold weather policy would shame UK snowflake headteachers, as Yakutsk primary schools always stay open as long as temperatures stay above -C.Locals use padded “car cozies” to cover vehicles and stop engines freezing solid. And taxi drivers run engines continuously for months to keep parts moving — adding to the city’s fug of pollution.Threat of frostbite is a constant challenge but locals know what to do. One granny told us yesterday: “If your nose or cheeks go white and numb oryou lose feelings in your hands put them in cold water. Never hot.”Despite the cold, student teachers Kira Ivanova and Vilena Egorova, both , were smiling as they headed to class past ice sculptures being honed yesterday in preparation for New Year celebrations.Kira said: “I’ve experienced - here a few years back and everything carried on pretty much as normal — I guess we’re just used to it.“So it’s hard for us to understand how people in Britain struggle to cope with any temperatures near to freezing.“Siberian cold is our gt to you — from Russia with love.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may woolly brexit deal
story: But it is still just a woolly and even contradictory wishlist that barely binds Brussels to anything.The cost of these vague promises  Some  thousand million pounds.This “political declaration” about the future is predicated on Brussels negotiating a trade deal in good faith, a ­quality they have never shown since the referendum result they are even now desperate to overthrow.Why would their puerile desire to “punish” Britain abate once we nominally leave next March Especially when under the terms now agreed they can trap us in the Customs Union for ever The PM claims the EU wouldn’t want us there, benefiting from it for free, having ended free movement. But that’s a price Brussels will surely pay to cripple us as a trading rival on their doorstep.That said, the deal is NOT all bad.Downing Street rightly trumpets that it ends free movement and our massive membership subscription, protects jobs and secures our fishing rights .And Mrs May, to her considerable credit, pushed the EU into an extraordinary U-turn over a high-tech solution to police the Irish border. Remember how glibly they once sneered at that idea Trouble is, who trusts them not to change heart againthe appalling “Irish backstop” alternative suits them The trade deal may take years. Anyone could veto it: Spain over Gibraltar. Or the Belgian Walloons who almost wrecked the EU Canada deal. We would be stuck.And while Mrs May’s deal enshrines our right to an independent trade policy, it also says any new partnership with the EU must “build on” a single customs territory.That’s why Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab quit — it ­scuppers any deals where.The one straw we clutch is that Jeremy Corbyn isn’t negotiating.None of his scripted lines, nor his brow furrowed in supposed concentration, can hide that the entire debate sails over his head.Don’t imagine the chaos couldn’t be worse.WE heartily approve of primary kids being tasked with damming streams, canoeing and playing conkers.Sure, it’s a bit Swallows And Amazons. And a big ask in Moss Side or Tower Hamlets. But children do spend far too much time gawping at screens.Education Secretary Damian Hinds wants that to change. All power to him.FOR years The Sun has condemned the web giants for facilitating terrorism.Now MPs have concluded the same: Google and Facebook are a “safe haven” for online extremists who radicalise and mould killers.If they will not purge their sites, vast fines must force them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cbi humiliated after leaked emails brexit
story: The Confederation of British Industrys Brexit boss described the draft trade agreement with Brussels unveiled by the PM yesterday as “not a good deal” in a memo mistakenly sent to ITV News.It laid bare the contrast in the CBI’s public and private verdict on the final Brexit arrangements negotiated by Mrs May.It came just three days after the boss of the business group, which represents , firms, hailed the draft agreement. The CBI had campaigned for Britain to stay in the EU’s single market and customs union permanently but reluctantly backed Mrs May’s deal on Monday. Brexiteers have long criticised the CBI for being too pro-EU and have branded the group the “voice of Brussels”. Their private criticism of the PM’s deal delighted Leave campaigners last night.On Monday CBI boss Carolyn Fairbairn said of the PM’s deal: “Its not perfect, its a compromise, but its progress. It takes us back from the clf edge, avoids no deal, charts potential path to future frictionless trade deal. That is progress, we should not go backwards.And her deputy Josh Hardie yesterday said Britain was “on the cusp on a much-needed agreement” after the Government published the -page Political Declaration, which outlines our future trading relationship with the EU.The document sets out a series of aspirations but lacks any legal grounding and is short on detail – in contrast with the  page Withdrawal Agreement, which is legally binding.He added: The progress made is a credit to both sets of negotiators. But hard work lies ahead“.But the private emails revealed the CBI was actually scathing of the PM and her negotiators and argued over whether they should be publicly praising them given it wasn’t a good deal.The CBI’s Head of EU Negotiations Nicole Sykes sent an internal email arguing that there was “no need to give credit to negotiators I think, because it’s not a good deal”.The quotation marks suggest serious doubts.It is also embarrassing for the Prime Minister, who sold her Brexit deal at the CBI annual conference on Monday – urging voters to “listen to what business is saying.”Former Tory MP and ex-Brexit advisor Stewart Jackson said: “Speaking with forked tongue for their own short term narrow interests  You could knock me down with a feather.”Labour MP Wes Streeting, who backs a second referendum, said: Despite the CBIs public support, it is clear that even the Government’s biggest business backers think this is a bad deal for Britain.There is no support in Parliament, among business or in the country for a deal which takes away control and makes people poorer.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa mays brexit deal branded sell out
story: She outlined the rough terms of a future trade deal in a -page political declaration — but also revealed that a post-Brexit transition deal could be extended until December .That is two years longer than originally suggested and would cost Britain an estimated £million for every month — on top of the £billion orce bill we must already pay to leave the EU.The agreement also leaves Britain tied to the hated European Court of Justice, which will still have the final say on any dispute over EU rules.The revelations incensed MPs who were already outraged by the concessions Britain has made. Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “The last thing we want is for Britain to be tied beyond .“The British people want us to get out. This is a sell-out.”Former Brexit Secretary David Davis said: “This is £billion for a pig in a poke.“The EU’s got nailed down everything it wants whilst leaving us on a half promise of what we want.”And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn called it “ pages of waffle”.He said: “The only certainty contained within these pages is that the transition period will have to be extended or we will end up with backstop and no exit.“It represents the worst of all worlds, no say over the rules that will continue to apply and no certainty to the future.”He accused the PM of producing a “blindfold Brexit from a government that spent more time negotiating with itself than for the nation”.In yesterday’s document, the EU agreed the UK can end free movement, try to negotiate deals with the rest of the world and take back control of fisheries.But the EU refused to accept that a future EU-UK trade deal will allow Mrs May “frictionless trade” and insisted the UK will be bound by EU rules on everything from state aid to climate change.And it only accepted that technology would be “considered” as a way of preventing theof a hard border in Irelanda future trade deal is not agreed.The terms will almost certainly be formally agreed by Mrs May and  other EU leaders at a crunch summit in Brussels on Sunday. This will trigger the orce bill of up to £billion.In a fierce Commons exchange, the PM resorted to urging MPs to back the deal when it goes before the Commons because the public is bored.She insisted “Brexit is within our grasp” adding: “The British people want Brexit to be settled.“They want a good deal that sets us on course for a brighter future.“And they want us to come together as a country and to move on to focus on the big issues at home, like our NHS.”She once more ruled out the prospect of a second referendum.And Downing Street insisted it will never happen “while she is Prime Minister”.But Brexiteers lined up to slam the agreement — fuelling concerns it will never make it through the Commons in a critical “Meaningful Vote” in three weeks’ time.More than  Tories are thought to be ready to vote down the deal — alongside the DUP, SNP and most Labour MPs.Cabinet ministers spent much of a conference call with Mrs May ­yesterday morning debating how to sell the deal to the nation.Last night Chief Whip Julian Smith emailed Tory MPs urging them to “unite” and back the PM. He told backbenchers: “If we reject this deal we go back to square one.“This would mean damaging uncertainty which will threaten jobs, investment and the economy.”Home Secretary Sajid Javid insisted the deal “delivers on the referendum” — although he admitted the Government must do a “better job of selling” it.But Boris Johnson said the terms of the Brexit deal made a “complete nonsense of Brexit”.And Brexiteers warned they could not support a deal which still included the so-called Irish backstop plan for keeping the border open.But Mrs May insisted it would only kick ina new trade deal isn’t in place by January .But it is still just a woolly and even contradictory wishlist that barely binds Brussels to anything.The cost of these vague promises Some  thousand million pounds.This “political declaration” about the future is predicated on Brussels negotiating a trade deal in good faith, a ­quality they have never shown since the referendum result they are even now desperate to overthrow.Why would their puerile desire to “punish” Britain abate once we nominally leave next March  Especially when under the terms now agreed they can trap us in the Customs Union for ever The PM claims the EU wouldn’t want us there, benefiting from it for free, having ended free movement. But that’s a price Brussels will surely pay to cripple us as a trading rival on their doorstep.That said, the deal is NOT all bad.Downing Street rightly trumpets that it ends free movement and our massive membership subscription, protects jobs and secures our fishing rights .And Mrs May, to her considerable credit, pushed the EU into an extraordinary U-turn over a high-tech solution to police the Irish border. Remember how glibly they once sneered at that idea Trouble is, who trusts them not to change heart againthe appalling “Irish backstop” alternative suits them The trade deal may take years. Anyone could veto it: Spain over Gibraltar. Or the Belgian Walloons who almost wrecked the EU Canada deal. We would be stuck.And while Mrs May’s deal enshrines our right to an independent trade policy, it also says any new partnership with the EU must “build on” a single customs territory. That’s why Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab quit — it ­scuppers any deals where.The one straw we clutch is that Jeremy Corbyn isn’t negotiating. None of his scripted lines, nor his brow furrowed in supposed concentration, can hide that the entire debate sails over his head.Don’t imagine the chaos couldn’t be worseOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
